story:
Creativa International presents For a Muse of Fire: a DTES community theatre initiative led by theatre artist Luisa Jojic in partnership with Vancouver Moving Theatre / Downtown Eastside Heart of the City Festival, the Lookout Emergency Aid Society, and RainCity Housing, with support from the City of Vancouver.

For a Muse of Fire is a community theatre project led by theatre artist Luisa Jojic  involving and open to diverse individuals who live, work or study in Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside (DTES) including those who have experienced homelessness or are currently vulnerably housed.

The project is an opportunity for local residents to explore, learn, create and transform through the art of theatre. Participants will collaborate to create an original live performance piece to be performed at Vancouver Moving Theatre's Heart of the City Festival (Oct-Nov 2015). It presents a counter narrative to the dominant portrayal of the DTES as a neighbourhood divided by income, culture and class, by bringing to light a fuller picture of the DTES as a place of strong community in which people learn from and support each other.

For a Muse of Fire builds on the success of Much Ado About SOMETHING, a pilot initiative led by Luisa Jojic in collaboration with RainCity Housing for Homelessness Action Week 2014. A group of 9 participants worked together to explore issues of class, equality, community and belonging, using Shakespeare's text as a starting point to create their own words and stories. The collaboratively created work was performed Oct 2014 at the Carnegie Centre, Waterfront Theatre, and Kwantlen Park Secondary School in Surrey.

"I don't usually feel powerful as a resident here, but in this project I had the community to express, give my voice and be heard - that is so valuable to me" - 2014 Project Participant

"I was reminded how much education, creativty and passion for life the DTES residents have. I usually just drive by and it's hard to know what people on the street are thinking" - 2014 Audience Member

For a Muse of Fire reunites Creativa International with the Lookout Emergency Aid Society, who partnered in 2013 to create a 100ft wide mural on the side of their North Vancouver shelter - a large-scale community arts initiative titled Word to Your Motherland that brought together internationally acclaimed street artists, homeless shelter residents, and local youth.


All funds will be received by the Lookout Emergency Aid Society (Federally Registered Charity No: 130695166 RR0001). Charitable tax receipts issued.

Donations by cheque are also gratefully received. Please make cheques payable to Lookout Emergency Aid Society specifying 'For a Muse of Fire' in the comment area, and mail to: Lookout Emergency Aid Society, 429 Alexander Street, Vancouver, BC V6A 1C6.

All donations will go directly to the project: towards honorariums for the participants, food during rehearsal, venue and equipment rental, and the creative team.

Team:

Luisa Jojic, Director

A professional performer, instructor, and director, Luisa has worked with a number of companies and artists since graduating from UBC in 2001 with a BFA in Theatre. As a theatre practitioner she has collaborated with The Arts Club, Bard on the Beach, The Vancouver Opera, Savage God, The Richmond Gateway Theatre, Theatre Northwest, The Centaur Theatre, Blackbird Theatre, Playwright's Theatre Centre (PTC), Playwright's Workshop Montreal (PWM), Theatre Terrific, Reel Wheels, Craning Neck, Radix, Leaky Heaven, Pound of Flesh, Theatre Conspiracy, The Chutzpah! Festival, and The Only Animal, among others. A classically trained actor who has performed on stages across the country, she has also spent a large part of her career also involved in the development of original Canadian work. Luisa is a regular participant in the Playwright Theatre Centre's Colony workshops, has twice toured the Canadian national Fringe circuit with original work, and her multi-media and installation performance work has been seen at the BC Bud’s Festival for Emerging Artists, The Signal and Noise Festival, Ladyfest, Sistahood, the Vancouver Out on Screen Festival, the Firenze Biannele in Florence, Italy, AC (Institute Direct) in New York City, and The Soapbox Gallery in Brooklyn, NY. Screen credits include CW's Supernatural, ABC’s Reaper, Fox Network’s Ace of Hearts and local features The Familiar, Love and Other Dilemmas, Mud Pies, and The Portside. Luisa has worked as an instructor in theater and movement with Arts Umbrella, and has been a Teaching Artist with Bard on the Beach since 2006. Through Bard in the Classroom, she facilitates workshops in schools throughout the lower mainland on Shakespeare. She is the Coordinator for The Young Shakespeareans Workshops- organizing 18 workshops over the course of the summer for over 250 participants. She is a founding member of The Riotous Youth mentorship program at Bard on the Beach, and of Bard in Your Neighbourhood-where she currently works with at-risk youth in a subsidised program for schools across the lower mainland. She has led workshops in acting and performance with the Out On Screen Festival, The Saltspring Centre, and the John Robert Powers Academy, and works as an acting and public speaking coach to individuals of all ages.
http://www.luisajojic.com


Tara Taylor, Stage Manager

Tara has been working in the DTES for over a decade. She brings a social justice approach in working with those experiencing homelessness and/or under-housing, and is committed to anti-oppressive care practices and grassroots advocacy. Her other interests include mental-health, harm-reduction, and community participation. Tara recognizes the harms, stigmas, and negative experiences many residents of the DTES have had, and tries to work with folks in a way that is responsive, collaborative, and accountable. Tara is excited to be working again with Luisa Jojic on this inclusive and community-driven project. This is their second project collaboration; the first being 2014’s successful ‘Much Ado About SOMETHING’ for the city’s Homelessness Action Week. Tara is honored to be a part of ‘For a Muse of Fire’ in partnership with Creativa International. She believes in safe, non-judgmental, and supportive community participation that celebrates creativity, resiliency, and self-empowerment.

Kate Declerck, Creativa International
Linda Fox, Lookout Emergency Aid Society
story_txt:
Creativa International presents For a Muse of Fire: a DTES community theatre 
initiative led by theatre artist Luisa Jojic in partnership with 
Vancouver Moving Theatre / Downtown Eastside Heart of the City Festival,
 the Lookout Emergency Aid Society, and RainCity Housing, with support from the City of Vancouver.
For a Muse of Fire is a community theatre project led by theatre artist Luisa Jojic  involving and open to diverse individuals who live, work or study in 
Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside (DTES) including those who have 
experienced homelessness or are currently vulnerably housed.
The project is an opportunity for local residents to explore, learn, 
create and transform through the art of theatre. Participants will 
collaborate to create an original live performance piece to be performed
 at Vancouver Moving Theatre's Heart of the City Festival
 (Oct-Nov 2015). It presents a counter narrative to the dominant 
portrayal of the DTES as a neighbourhood divided by income, culture and 
class, by bringing to light a fuller picture of the DTES as a place of 
strong community in which people learn from and support each other.
For a Muse of Fire builds on the success of Much Ado About SOMETHING,
 a pilot initiative led by Luisa Jojic in collaboration with RainCity 
Housing for Homelessness Action Week 2014. A group of 9 participants 
worked together to explore issues of class, equality, community and 
belonging, using Shakespeare's text as a starting point to create their 
own words and stories. The collaboratively created work was performed 
Oct 2014 at the Carnegie Centre, Waterfront Theatre, and Kwantlen Park 
Secondary School in Surrey.
"I don't usually feel powerful as a resident here, but in this 
project I had the community to express, give my voice and be heard - 
that is so valuable to me" - 2014 Project Participant
"I was reminded how much education, creativty and passion for life 
the DTES residents have. I usually just drive by and it's hard to know 
what people on the street are thinking" - 2014 Audience Member
For a Muse of Fire reunites Creativa International with the Lookout 
Emergency Aid Society, who partnered in 2013 to create a 100ft wide 
mural on the side of their North Vancouver shelter - a large-scale 
community arts initiative titled Word to Your Motherland that brought together internationally acclaimed street artists, homeless shelter residents, and local youth. 
All funds will be received by the Lookout Emergency Aid 
Society (Federally Registered Charity No: 130695166 RR0001). Charitable tax 
receipts issued.
Donations by cheque are also gratefully received. Please make
 cheques payable to Lookout Emergency Aid Society specifying
 'For a Muse of Fire' in the comment area, and mail to: Lookout Emergency Aid Society, 429 Alexander 
Street, Vancouver, BC V6A 1C6.All donations will go directly to the project: towards honorariums for the participants, food during rehearsal, venue and equipment rental, and the creative team.Team:Luisa Jojic, DirectorA professional performer, instructor, and director, Luisa has worked 
with a number of companies and artists since graduating from UBC in 2001
 with a BFA in Theatre. As a theatre practitioner she has collaborated 
with The Arts Club, Bard on the Beach, The Vancouver Opera, Savage God, 
The Richmond Gateway Theatre, Theatre Northwest, The Centaur Theatre, 
Blackbird Theatre, Playwright's Theatre Centre (PTC), Playwright's 
Workshop Montreal (PWM), Theatre Terrific, Reel Wheels, Craning Neck, 
Radix, Leaky Heaven, Pound of Flesh, Theatre Conspiracy, The Chutzpah! 
Festival, and The Only Animal, among others. A classically trained actor
 who has performed on stages across the country, she has also spent a 
large part of her career also involved in the development of original 
Canadian work. Luisa is a regular participant in the Playwright Theatre 
Centre's Colony workshops, has twice toured the Canadian national Fringe
 circuit with original work, and her multi-media and installation 
performance work has been seen at the BC Bud’s Festival for Emerging 
Artists, The Signal and Noise Festival, Ladyfest, Sistahood, the 
Vancouver Out on Screen Festival, the Firenze Biannele in Florence, 
Italy, AC (Institute Direct) in New York City, and The Soapbox Gallery 
in Brooklyn, NY. Screen credits include CW's Supernatural, ABC’s Reaper,
 Fox Network’s Ace of Hearts and local features The Familiar, Love and 
Other Dilemmas, Mud Pies, and The Portside. Luisa has worked as an 
instructor in theater and movement with Arts Umbrella, and has been a 
Teaching Artist with Bard on the Beach since 2006. Through Bard in the 
Classroom, she facilitates workshops in schools throughout the lower 
mainland on Shakespeare. She is the Coordinator for The Young 
Shakespeareans Workshops- organizing 18 workshops over the course of the
 summer for over 250 participants. She is a founding member of The 
Riotous Youth mentorship program at Bard on the Beach, and of Bard in 
Your Neighbourhood-where she currently works with at-risk youth in a 
subsidised program for schools across the lower mainland. She has led 
workshops in acting and performance with the Out On Screen Festival, The
 Saltspring Centre, and the John Robert Powers Academy, and works as an 
acting and public speaking coach to individuals of all ages. 
http://www.luisajojic.comTara Taylor, Stage ManagerTara has been working in the DTES for over a decade. She brings a social
 justice approach in working with those experiencing homelessness and/or
 under-housing, and is committed to anti-oppressive care practices and 
grassroots advocacy. Her other interests include mental-health, 
harm-reduction, and community participation. Tara recognizes the harms, 
stigmas, and negative experiences many residents of the DTES have had, 
and tries to work with folks in a way that is responsive, collaborative,
 and accountable. Tara is excited to be working again with Luisa Jojic 
on this inclusive and community-driven project. This is their second 
project collaboration; the first being 2014’s successful ‘Much Ado About
 SOMETHING’ for the city’s Homelessness Action Week.

Tara is honored to be a part of ‘For a Muse of Fire’ in partnership with

story:
This is an opportunity to make a contribution to one of the most important campaigns of our times.  The Steve Sinnott Foundation works to promote the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals for education to secure access to quality education for every child and young person in the world, Education for All.

We're raising money here to make three short animated films. At under 1 minute each, these powerful films telling personal stories of changing lives through accessing education, will be used by us to aid an understanding of the work that we do to provide access to learning worldwide. They will be shown in schools, at conferences, in talks, on our website and to aid learning and fundraising activities. We will also be creating learning resources for schools with the money raised. People have asked us which personal stories we will tell through the animated films. The answer is that we don't know yet. We'll be  asking members of our friends community to vote for the best three.

The Steve Sinnott Foundation was established in 2009 in the name of Steve Sinnott, General Secretary of the National Union of Teachers of England and Wales.  Behind the headlines of his work as head of the NUT, Steve was an enthusiastic and active promoter of the United Nations Millennium Development Goals for education (now updated to the Sustainable Development Goals). He often spoke of education as ‘the great liberator’ which provides a pathway out of poverty and despair. There are 55 million children still without access to quality education so there is still much more work to be done. You can find out more about The Steve Sinnott Foundation here www.stevesinnottfoundation.org.uk

Our film team

Lucy Lee graduated from the National Film & TV School, winning the Chicago Gold Hugo award amongst others, with her graduation film which she made in Russia. She has since made numerous other independent and commissioned films on a wide range of topics and in a wide range of styles, and won awards around the globe. You can see more of her work here www.instinctmedia.co.uk

Stelios Koupetoris has been nominated for his work, including Lucy Lee's "Wasteland" at the UK Music and Sound Awards, the Hollywood Music in Media Awards and has been awarded at the Garden State Film Festival, the Drama Film Festival and the Park City Film Music Festival among others. 

Nefeli Stamatogiannopoulou studied music at the Royal School of Music and acquired her Bachelor and MMus in Composition for Film, Theater and Performing Arts at the Ionian University of Greece. She collaborates with the renowned Grotowski Institute and composes for films and theatre. Nefeli is also the founder of the band "Spooky RedRum".

Louise Brown is an award winning sound editor and Foley artist. She has worked on films such as "Moshi Monsters: The Movie", "Anuvahood", "Plastic" and "Tower Block". Louise also enjoys working with young people to foster their creativity.

Why tell personal stories?

Because they are more interesting.  They touch us, make us feel alive, and inspire us. They reflect our basic human need to understand each other, our cultures and how others see the world.  Stories are the way in which people reach out and emotionally connect with each other. Storytelling enables people to share their ideas and solutions and not feel alone.

How will we find the stories?

From our work at the Foundation we meet many people who have compelling stories they want to share. As well as these, we are also asking people to send in their personal stories, and we'll be asking you, our community of supporters to vote for the best of all these stories. 

Why mini films?

Because they are infinitely viewable. Keeping it short keeps attention. Watch them and you can fill in the rest of the story.

What’s the money for?

Here’s the breakdown:
          50% Animation and Editing
          20% Music and Sound
          10% Story Competition
          20% Rewards and Resources, Indigogo fees

What are the Resources for Schools?

The films themselves, branded stationery to say thank you for fundraising, the booklet of stories, workshop resource packs.

What's in it for you?

You are actually the ones who are making this happen. You are adding to the EDUCATION FOR ALL movement. You are helping people share their stories, stories that can help and encourage others, stories that will help us understand each other. 

Education empowers people, gives people choices. It can create a different world, a better connected world, new opportunities for economic development and new hopes and aspirations for tens, maybe hundreds, of millions

Education, learning and knowledge are the proven opponents of war and conflict. They provide opportunities to enable people to escape from the deprivation which breeds anger and resentment, the cause of so much conflict. 

Investing now in education is an investment in all our futures.

story:
***We set a goal of $1,200, but we hope to exceed that with your help. This project is vital to our community.***


Our Vision

We're transforming an old building in the heart of Bethlehem to a library and resource center. The center will focus on two areas: the history and contemporary community of Bethlehem and the general study of peacemaking, nonviolence and conflict resolution. Books, digital media and specialized research materials will be available on both subjects. This will be the first center of its kind in Palestine. Researchers, international visitors, students and the general public will be able to access historical data on Bethlehem that merges theoretical and historical perspectives. They will also be be able to access materials on peacemaking in a region of conflict, where these materials have a direct, immediate, real world application.


So it's a Library?

The Peace Research Center (PRC) will be more than a collection of research materials. In addition to the materials available, we will be sponsoring weekly programming and activities, including:

 

* Film Screenings and Premiers

* Nonviolence Trainings / Workshops. 

* Seminars and Guest Speakers

* Local Women's Forums

* Community Dialogues

* Cross Cultural Encounters / Exchanges

* Children's Programming and Activities

 

What Help do We Need?

We have the space! Now we just need to utilize it. It's not enough to have the walls and books, we need a small amount of money for human resources and funds for programming as well. With your help we can turn an empty building into a living, breathing center, available to both the local community and international researchers and guests. We can train local community members in the theory and practice of nonviolence, host a women's circle, open up the center for film screenings, and create an open space for community dialogue. We want Bethlehem to be known as a center of peacemaking, rather than a center of conflict and division. Please consider partnering with us on this project. A small donation can have a lasting impact felt for years to come.


Why This is Important

This project has the opportunity to be transformative not just for our community, but for the international community as well. There is a long history of nonviolent resistance and peace building here. We want to build on this legacy and move toward a shared future, in which not just local community members, but also those in the international community, can learn from the experiences and history of the Palestinian context. 


Who We Are

Holy Land Trust (HLT) is a not-for-profit organization established in Bethlehem in 1998. HLT seeks to empower the community through mobilizing its strengths and resources in order to address the challenges of the present and create real opportunities for the future.


Through a commitment to the principles of nonviolence, the Holy Land Trust seeks to strengthen and empower the Palestinian community in developing spiritual, pragmatic and strategic approaches that will allow it to resist all forms of oppression and build a future that makes the Holy Land a global model and pillar of understanding, respect, justice, equality and peaceful coexistence.

story:
Our Story

I've been teaching children for over 10 years and it's my passion. I've created a successful art & music program for preschoolers called ArtSmart with Miss Patti.  www.nyartsmart.com
ArtSmart introduces preschoolers, age 2 to 6, to the world of famous art as they have fun recreating works by Picasso, Monet, Van Gogh and more. Then it's off to play music as they join the band and learn music terminology in a fun and groovy way!


ArtSmart, the tv show will be a condensed version of the program I've been teaching in NYC, Westchester & CT and will feature original songs from the cd "Feeling Groovy With Miss Patti".

In addition to filming the pilot, we'll also be shooting 3 music videos from 'Feeling Groovy'. We will have a DVD package which will include the music videos and the pilot episode of ArtSmart with Miss Patti.

We are brainstorming with creatives from some of the top production houses in New York. Think Little Einsteins meets Banana Splits meets Blues Clues. We will be pitching to the big 3..Disney, Nickelodeon & PBS.  There will be animation elements and merchandising opportunities that the networks will be drooling over, such as the plush toy, Picasso The Parrot, based on a character in the show who is my animated friend. There's a DIY ArtSmart book in the works, magic ArtSmart smocks, art supplies, DVD & CD's...The Feeling Groovy Band will tour to support the show...we're just getting started!  And I do mean WE...My partner,  Kevin Hupp,  is in charge of the music/sound for the show, as well as co-writer of many of the songs. Kevin's credits include working with many talented professionals such as Eddie Van Halen, Rufus Wainwright, Iggy Pop, Maceo Parker, Joan Osborne, Rick Derringer.  You can check him out  @ www.kevcomusicgroup.com.

The Impact

We have a powerful tool in television and the web. I believe strongly in using the media to supplement all our educations.  ArtSmart with Miss Patti will be a valuable addition to preschool television programming on a national level as more and more parents are forced to make tough decisions.  Budgets are being cut across the board and preschool has become a luxury in many areas of our country. We need quality programming and ArtSmart is an educational, fun, unique program that fills a void in today's early childhood education. ArtSmart will teach children art history & music terminology. Viewers will develop their fine & gross motor skills, as well as their vocabulary. Adults will learn alongside their children, as ArtSmart gives a fresh new perspective to art & music.


What if our campaign doesn't happen? If we can't raise the goal, I'm confident we will raise enough to shoot a sizzle (baseline pilot) and 3 music videos to attract more investors and national attention to give ArtSmart TV more 'juice'.  I am being very efficient and conservative with the shooting schedule & crew so we get the most bang for the buck.  I am storyboarding everything (saving time/$ on the director), we are shooting at a gorgeous, donated location (saving time/$ on a soundstage), and how lucky am I to have Kevin doing the sound/music? (saving $ on a music supervisor/sound engineer). In our current economy, there are so many creative people willing to work and negotiate that we have and will continue to attract talented specialists that will bring ArtSmart TV to life.  Whenever I see a project clearly, it manifests. That is how I see ArtSmart with Miss Patti. I hope you can see it, too! If not, please send me your questions to help me give you the big picture.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is a breakdown of the budget to shoot the pilot of ArtSmart & up to 3 music videos from my cd. We may be able to shoot more videos, but that will be determined during the shoot. You know I'm going for as many as we can!

$1k in trademark/licensing fees

$2500 lawyer fees (have to make sure the i's are dotted and t's are crossed)

$3500 for crew (producer, director/shooter, lighting, stage crew, makeup, set designer, food/transportation)

$5000 post production (animation, graphics, editing, mastering, duplication)


Depending on your contribution, you will receive one or more of the following:

signed cd's & photos

a private ArtSmart party

be my guest behind the scenes at the shoot

your child or friend cast in the show/video

a private performance by The Feeling Groovy Band

credits in the show 


Other Ways You Can Help

It Takes A Village! You can help TREMENDOUSLY by getting the word out and making some noise about my campaign. Whether you can contribute today or not, would you share this site with your friends who have friends that know friends? 

Are you in the biz? Photographer? Publicist? Agent? Got some contacts? Makeup artist? Graphic designer? Animator? Contact me to get involved.

THANK YOU!!

a private performance by The Feeling Groovy Band
credits in the show 


Other Ways You Can Help
It Takes A Village! You can help TREMENDOUSLY by getting the word out and making some noise about my campaign. Whether you can contribute today or not, would you share this site with your friends who have friends that know friends? 
Are you in the biz? Photographer? Publicist? Agent? Got some contacts? Makeup artist? Graphic designer? Animator? Contact me to get involved.
THANK YOU!!

story:
Who are you?

I'm Miya David and I'm a reporter from the Philippines about to embark on the biggest thing to ever happen in my life.

I've been accepted to grad school in New York to study specialized journalism. It's been my biggest dream ever to study journalism and to do it in New York, arguably one of the centers of media, is quite possibly the best thing ever and I get to come back to my country and share what I learned.

But sadly, as an international student and a working journalist, I don't exactly have enough financial liquidity for grad school (collective *sigh*).

What for?

The idea of this campaign is to help defray tuition.

I applied to several scholarships but since it's very competitive (and apparently my clout isn't as big as I thought), I haven't gotten any. But not to worry, I'm applying for several loans in the US which require me to have  US co-signer and local loans here in my country.

Also, several scholarships require me to be enrolled and applications start this December. And the lottery. Cross your fingers!

Let's break it down though.

The $15,000 I'm aiming for will be used for:

  • One semester's worth of tuition which is $10,165
  • Supplement living expenses including rent, food and possibly the Macbook Pro I'm required to have

What's gonna happen?

No really why should I give money to you?

Like I said, this is probably the biggest thing ever for me.

I'm going to take up an MA in Journalism and I will be focusing on Arts Journalism using a multimedia platform.

Basically, what I want to do is report on the changing production of the arts. See, most people now get to enjoy something artistic like say a movie or a TV show if they download it. So how do we gauge its popularity? How do we report a certain movie's impact on people when most discussions happen not when people leave the theater but on the Internet. I want to be able to report on the many different ways people from different corners of the world come together through cultural products like movies, books, plays all through the Internet.

After grad school, I can practice what I learned in my country and hopefully inspire other media people to think critically about how the arts and artistic products are being enjoyed here.

Other Ways I Can Help?

Wait! What if I want to do more? Well here's how:

  • Spread the word! Share it on Twitter, Facebook, Tumblr, LiveJournal, comms, forums or the billboard in the nearest major thoroughfare
  • Know any more fund raising ideas? Scholarships? Grants? Loans? Well drop me a line and let me know!
  • Pray, wish and keep a positive attitude
  • Oh and use the share tools here in Indiegogo!
You can always contact me through my email miya.david@gmail.com, my official twitter http://twitter.com/miyadavid or through my Facebook account (introduce yourself though, I'd like to know who I'm talking to)

story:
I am Yashsvi Singh, a student of B Tech III Year in Civil Engineering, VNIT (Visvesvarya National Institute of Technology), Nagpur. I am pleased to inform you that I have been selected for summer research internship program at Laval University in Quebec, Canada.Laval University is North America's first francophone higher education institution and it is one of Canada's leading research universities. .

Laval University has no provision of funding International Intern students. Therefore, I’ll have to manage cost involved in travel and stay during the intern period.

Hence, I appeal you to provide financial assistance to me for making it possible to complete the internship at Laval University.

This Internship will not only give me an opportunity to gain knowledge on the projects I want to work for after my graduation but will also help objectives adopted by VNIT to rise to a global platform.

Estimated details of the basic expenses that you can assist me with partially or completely as you may feel necessary:

· Internship Project : Assisting a Canadian master’s student on the project about bioremediation potential of affected sub-Arctic soils in Canada.

· Internship Location : Laval University, Quebec, Canada

· Internship Date : May 10-July 10, 2015 ( 8 WEEKS PROGRAM)

· Air Fare : Canadian $1400-$1500 (INR 70000-INR 76500) roundtrip

· Accommodation in Laval University Campus : Canadian $1000-$1200 (INR 50000-INR 60000) total for two month stay

Total Financial Support requested partially or completely: Canadian -$2700

i.e. INR 1,35,000

With my family’s assistance I can manage some of the total amount and the incidentals to complete my Internship in Laval University, Quebec, Canada.

This Internship is a lifetime opportunity for any student and having your support I will be able to complete this Research project successfully and add an achievement not only in my life but also payback to VNIT.

Thanking you in anticipation,

Yours faithfully,

Yashsvi Singh

(+91)-9970504690

(+91)-9799591494

12BT03CIV091

Civil Engineering Department

VNIT, Nagpur-440010

story:
Let's go outside!

This is the second annual Smithdown Road Festival, a free non-profit festival of music, art, theatre, dance and food in South Liverpool! It runs over the May Day bank holiday weekend - 30th April to 2nd May 2016.

Last year, we packed out the bars and cafes along the street to bursting point, with some of the city's best and brightest bands attracting hundreds of festival goers along for the weekend.

This year, we want to go one better and have an outdoor element to the festival, with a massive circus big top on The Mystery (Wavertree Park) hosting more well known bands and bigger audiences. There will also be a range of food stalls from the local restaurants and eateries, a dedicated family friendly kids area and even a pro-wrestling event!
We are also using this year's event as opportunity to raise a lot of money for The Whitechapel Centre, who do amazing work for homeless people in Merseyside.
Your contribution to the festival will ensure not only can we achieve this aim in 2016, but set down the benchmark for a fantastic free event in Liverpool for years to come.


What We Need & What You Get

While we already have some additional funding from the local business community, and we are awaiting funding from the Arts Council, we're after £8,500 of your hard earned money to make this happen. Sounds like a lot, but when you break it down it all makes sense!

It'll pay for -
- The big top (approx. £3000 hire) 
- Stage and PA (approx. £2500 hire)
- Fencing, toilets, lighting (approx. £1500 hire)
- Security and stewards (approx. £1500 wages)

In return (apart from an awesome free festival) you can get -
- A stage named after you
- Exclusive discount wristbands
- T shirts, tote bags, badges
- Limited edition branded festival beer glasses
- Even more limited edition prints
- A signed festival poster
- Best Of The Festival compilation album
- Wrestling lessons and tickets from Infinite Wrestling
- A party in your house with a live band, food and drinks!
- Thanks in our festival guide
- High fives, beers and burritos


If we are very close to the target then we will make every effort to get the additional sponsorship from local businesses we need in order to achieve our goal of adding a big outside element to the festival.
If we go over the target? Well, that just means we can pay for improvements and more well known acts in the future, to make sure your festival experience is even better for years to come!

The Impact

This event is so important for the Smithdown area, and Liverpool as a whole. We are aiming to bring the community together through music and art, and breathe some new life into a part of the city that has been somewhat neglected in recent years.

Last year's event was a huge success on a smaller scale, and so we really hope that by adding on an outside element to the festival we can increase the appeal to a wider audience that might not just want to watch music in a bar or café.



Risks & Challenges

There are several bumps in the road ahead, but we are confident that we can overcome any challenges that come our way. With the experience we gained from this festival last year, coupled with our individual experiences of running large outdoor events (one of the organisers has also been responsible for outdoor events at the Grand National), we will run this year's festival responsibly and efficiently. All the while sticking to a tight budget.  
The biggest restraint is time, and we are all working 48 hours a day to make this happen!


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help!
We need volunteers for our street teams to promote the festival, we need stewards to make sure things run smoothly and most of all we need people to share this fundraising page to make it all happen!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Send books to Ghana!

A Ban Against Neglect (ABAN) is a non-profit organization whose goal is to break the cycle of poverty for young Ghanaian women and mothers! We do this through entrepreneurship classes, vocational skills training, childcare, and employment opportunities for young mothers!

One thing our campus in Ghana is missing is a library! We have been collecting books from generous donors over the past few months and the only thing left to do is ship them to Ghana!

What's Left to Be Done

With the $500 funding we receive from your help and involvement with our Indiegogo campaign, we will be able to afford shipping a box of books and educational materials that weighs just under 60 lbs. (58 to be exact). The official language of Ghana is English, so we really want to invest in increasing their English skills to make them the most qualified candidates for jobs after graduating from our two-year social enterprise empowerment program. We also want to help give the children a good start to learning English, while they're young and able learners.

Your Impact

With your help, we will grow our support network and be able provide our women and children with a library. This will provide them access to books all the time - books for women to read, little easy-readers for children to explore, and children's stories that the women can read to their children at night because who doesn't love a good bedtime story?

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford donating money right now, that's ok! You can still be a part of our campaign on a different level! 

  • Share this campaign's information with your friends and family! Word of mouth never fails to spread the word like wildfire! (Indiegogo has share tools like Facebook and Twitter to help you out)
  • Check out our website, aban.org/handmade-in-ghana, where you can buy all types of products (bags, wallets, computer cases, etc.) for your loved ones or for yourself, whether it be for a holiday, birthday, or any occasion you want to spread some love and joy! 

We thank you a thousand times for checking out our page and being involved in any capacity that fits you! We hope you continue to support us even when this campaign comes to an end. Read more about ABAN and how it came to be at our website!

story:
Tennis After-School Programming: Chicago & Baltimore

The ACE Project’s programs build social emotional competencies, athletic skills, and educational fortitude in children ages 5-18. 

Tennis is our vehicle.

We were founded in February, 2013 and since then, approximately 425 youth have participated in our programming.  In the last year, we have facilitated multiple year-round camps partnering with local school districts and NGOs in the Chicago and Baltimore community. 

Most of our youth have never played tennis before or have only played at one of our ACE tennis camps.

All of our programming is free.  We are completely dependent on grants and fundraising.   

Taken at Pitts-Ashburton Elementary, Baltimore, MD


Teaching Personal and Social Responsibility (TPSR) Skills

The ACE Project uses evidence-based strategies for implementing our sports-based after school programming.  Using Don Hellison’s TPSR model (1995, 2011), we focus on five core components: 1) respecting the rights and feelings of others; 2) effort and cooperation; 3) self-direction; 4) helping others and leadership; and 5) transference outside the program.  These five components are emphasized in every session. 

Taken at Washington Elementary, Riverdale, IL.

The first 5-10 minutes of every session is used as a “check in” where our coaches ask about the participants’ day.  This is also when we teach social emotional components (e.g., listening, respect, etc.).  The majority of the session is then comprised of participants playing various tennis activities that fit that social emotional skill.  To conclude each session, there is a short meeting to process the tennis activities and a space is allowed for youth to self-rate (e.g., good, so-so, poor) their behavior.

Taken at Washington Elementary, Riverdale, IL.


Partnering with Parents, Public School Districts, and Community Organizations

We build community everywhere we go! 

Our coaching staff is primarily comprised of members of the local school community.  We train classroom teachers, office staff, lunch monitors, and crossing guards as well as parents and other adults who live in the community.

 Taken at Riverdale Park District, Riverdale, IL

We also partner with local churches and facilitate drop-in tennis clinics for community organizations with after school programs.

Taken outside of the Harlem Park Recreation Center, near UM-United and UM-Metropolitan Churches, Baltimore, MD

During the summer, we draw chalk lines for 36’ and 60’ youth tennis courts…


…and we pop-up tennis nets anywhere!

Both pictures taken at a vacant lot near Pinderhughes Elementary, Baltimore, MD.


Finding Opportunities for our Tennis Community

We seek to broaden children’s experiences. 

In Chicago, we bring a bus filled with eager tennis players to Winnetka and Homewood- Flossmoor, where local clubs host professional and college tennis matches for our youth to watch.  The day is also filled with on-court tennis activities, lunch, and a Q & A with nationally-ranked professional tennis players.   

This year, we hope to build traveling teams across both program sites in Chicago and Baltimore, where our players train with local tennis professionals and play in beginner junior USTA tournaments.

Fundraising will allow us to maintain current field trips and expand programming for our returning tennis players.

Taken at AC Nielsen Tennis Center, Winnetka, IL.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR INTEREST IN SUPPORTING OUR PROGRAMMING!

story:
Help us bring an innovative non-profit software company to Portland, and give our adults on the autism spectrum hope through community, technology training, and a safe work environment.

It is important to open nonPareil Portland now because in the United States, approximately 90% of adults on the autism spectrum are unemployed or underemployed and 70% will be unable to live independently. As a result, many families are left with having to ask the tough questions: "What will happen when the school bus stops coming?", "What happens after high school?", and "Who will take care of them when I'm gone?" Typically having limited social skills, many autistic young adults find themselves isolated, lonely, and generally not part of the community; this can often lead to high anxiety, depression and a general feeling of unfulfillment.

In response, a program out of Texas called nonPareil (meaning “no equal”), has developed a very unique model: it is a non-profit software company, intent on employing individuals with ASD. NonPareil trains students on the autism spectrum to develop, program, and design original video games and apps for the marketplace. By valuing each Crewmember’s distinct gifts and talents, nonPareil Institute engages interests and provides students with creative and meaningful long-term work, and the hope of employment income based on their product sales.

To generate initial awareness for nonPareil Portland, marketing professor Justine Haigh and key local stakeholders, partnered with George Fox University to host a two-day gaming programming camp at George Fox during the spring break of March 2014. The camp was a huge success with many inspiring stories from everyone who was involved - See for yourself, watch our short game programming camp video! http://vimeo.com/92096234

The next step in launching nonPareil Portland is to raise $10,000 in donations to fund a Programming Hope Portland Event. You will have the opportunity to meet founders Dan Selec and Gary Moore as well as the nonPareil Portland team. You will hear student success stories and family life-changing moments from both Texas Crewmembers and those who recently attended the Portland game programming camp. For those more interested in technology, there will be programming demonstrations and exhibits of Crewmembers creative, original designs (games and apps).

Our stretch goal is $160,000, which will allow us to open a local Portland office. With the additional funds, we will accelerate our plans and open our first nP PDX permanent location http://www.npitx.org/city/portland.aspx

Please help us by supporting our campaign and by spreading the word about nP in general. Considering the great demand for this program nationally, it is such a privilege to have the opportunity for nonPareil to come to Portland!

Want more details? Read on…

Nationally, autism diagnosis has reached an almost epidemic level. In March 2014, the Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) released its most recent update on the rates of autism in the United States. The statistics indicate that a rate of 1 out of 68 eight-year-old children are now diagnosed with ASD. http://healthyliving.msn.com/diseases/autism/us-autism-estimates-rise-by-30-percent-for-kids-1

Given these rates, a record number of autistic individuals are about to enter the workforce, enroll in college, or look for adult services. nonPareil Institute, with its unique methodology, has ‘changed the game’ in creating new opportunities for people with autism. Dan Selec, software developer and father to an autistic teenage son, started nonPareil at his kitchen table four years ago with just a handful of students. Today there is great demand for places at nonPareil Institute in Texas, with 150 students currently in the program and over 1,000 who have applied for admission.

nP has been featured in numerous reports and programs including: Huffington Post, NPR, CNN, and NBC’s Nightly News http://whatsnext.blogs.cnn.com/2013/07/12/creating-a-school-for-autistic-adults-one-student-at-a-time/?iref=allsearch

To see the impact that nP is having on its Crewmembers lives, be sure to watch this quick video http://programminghope.com/videos/336/?fb_ref=widget

What happened at our game programming camp?

It was evident from hosting our two-day gaming programming camp in March, that nonPareil Institute needs to expand to the Northwest. Even with minimal outreach, we received multiple camp applications and numerous inquiries (unsurprising since Oregon has one of the highest autism rates in the America for children ages 6-17) http://graphics.latimes.com/usmap-autism-rates-state/

The outcome was that our camp was a big hit! See us in the Newberg Graphic http://portlandtribune.com/nbg/142-news/215815-75586-game-programming-camp-for-autistic-adults-a-hit

The students loved interacting with the founder of the program Dan Selec, who came out from Texas to teach the camp, along with two of his amazing autistic staff trainers, “I love feeling part of something so great, I guess it’s that sense of community.”

Everyone was highly engaged with the material and the students left feeling accepted, confident, and with a new sense of purpose. The feeling of accomplishment could be seen in many of the students’ testimonials, “I can’t wait to have more experiences like this.”

Parents and families equally left feeling excited and hopeful for the future, “This was a wonderful opportunity for my son. I have absolutely no regrets…I love seeing opportunities out there for older children with autism. This is where the support for them starts to fall apart and to see the possibilities was truly exciting. Thank you!”

Thanks to all who helped out, particularly the mentors and volunteers, “Witnessing the creativity, social networking, and the overall community nonPareil fosters was truly amazing. They are leading a movement in understanding the way (individuals) with autism learn…”

Overall, we had an awesome time and it was great seeing everyone come together to support this important cause – let’s keep the momentum going!

As mentioned previously, we need to raise $10,000 in donations to host a Programming Hope Portland Event. Beyond the event, we hope to raise a further $160,000 to open a local office and then generate enough funds to open a permanent Portland location.

We can’t possibly know everyone touched by autism in the nearby area, so we really need your help! Please share with all your friends and contacts – this will greatly increase our chances of making this vision a reality.

Thank you to the many amazing people who have helped us get this far;

  • Dan Selec and Gary Moore, nonPareil Institute founders.
  • Justine Haigh, Max Janasik, David Brebner, and Walter and Koko Reyes, the nonPareil Portland team, who have gone over and above in giving their time and expertise.
  • Chris Meade, Ryan Halley, and Jeff VandenHoek from the George Fox University College of Business.
  • Bob Harder, Gary Spivey, Brent Wilson, and Mike Campadore from the George Fox University College of Engineering and thanks GFU for the use of the computer labs and equipment for the game programming camp!
  • Taylor Gerik and Aaron Winson, the amazing nonPareil staff trainers, who came with Dan from Texas to help teach the game programming camp.
  • Phil Autrey, Chris Elston, and the George Fox University media students, who did an amazing job in producing our fundraising video.
  • Courtney Minor, Aaron Dinwiddie, Katelyn Martin, AJ Spivey, and Savannah Cordry, as well as Deb Worden and Colleen Huffman (from the GFU COB), who gave up their time to help out with the game programming camp.
  • Steve Everley and Debbie Mylander from Velare Media, for their social media support.
  • Skip Newberry and Thompson Morrison (TAO) as well as Deb Mumm-Hill and Jeffrey Sens, for all of your advice and for helping us to spread the word.
  • Genevieve Athens and Diane Cervi (Autism Society of Oregon), for helping us to spread the word amongst the autism community.
  • Last, but certainly not least - many thanks to all the families and amazing students who attended the game programming camp, and to those featured in our game camp video. It’s for your success and for your future that we diligently pursue this worthy purpose!

Contact us

Email: portland@npitx.org

Website: http://www.npitx.org/city/portland.aspx

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/nonPareilPortland
story_txt:
Help
us bring an innovative non-profit software company to Portland, and give our
adults on the autism spectrum hope through community, technology training, and
a safe work environment.

It is important to open nonPareil Portland now because in
the United States, approximately 90% of adults on the autism spectrum are
unemployed or underemployed and 70%
will be unable to live independently. As a result, many families
are left with having to ask the tough questions: "What will happen when the
school bus stops coming?", "What happens after high school?", and "Who will take care of them when I'm
gone?" Typically having limited
social skills, many autistic young adults find themselves isolated, lonely, and
generally not part of the community; this can often lead to high anxiety,
depression and a general feeling of unfulfillment.In response, 
a program out of Texas called nonPareil (meaning
“no equal”), 
has developed a very unique model: it is a non-profit
software company, intent on employing individuals with ASD. NonPareil trains
students on the autism spectrum to develop, program, and design original video
games and apps for the marketplace. By valuing each Crewmember’s distinct gifts and talents,
nonPareil Institute engages interests
and provides students with creative and meaningful long-term work, and the hope
of employment income based on their product sales.



To generate initial
awareness for nonPareil Portland, marketing professor Justine Haigh and key
local stakeholders, partnered with George
Fox University to host a two-day gaming programming camp at George Fox
during the spring break of March 2014. The camp was a huge
success with many inspiring stories from everyone who was involved - See for yourself, watch our
short game programming camp video! http://vimeo.com/92096234

The next step in launching nonPareil Portland is to raise $10,000 in donations to fund a
Programming Hope Portland Event. You will have the opportunity to meet founders Dan
Selec and Gary Moore as well as the nonPareil
Portland team. You
will hear student success stories and family life-changing moments from
both Texas Crewmembers and those who recently attended the Portland game
programming camp. For those more interested in technology, there
will be programming demonstrations and exhibits of Crewmembers creative,
original designs (games and apps).
Our stretch goal is $160,000, which will
allow us to open a local Portland office. With the additional funds, we will accelerate
our plans and open our first nP PDX permanent location http://www.npitx.org/city/portland.aspx
Please help us by supporting our campaign and by spreading the
word about nP in general. Considering the great demand for this program nationally, it is such a privilege to
have the opportunity for nonPareil to come to Portland! 

Want more details? Read on…


Nationally, autism diagnosis has reached an almost epidemic level. 
In March 2014, the Center
for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) released its most recent update on the
rates of autism in the United States. The
statistics indicate that a rate of 1 out of 68 eight-year-old children are now
diagnosed with ASD. http://healthyliving.msn.com/diseases/autism/us-autism-estimates-rise-by-30-percent-for-kids-1
Given these
rates, a record number of autistic individuals are
about to enter the workforce, enroll in college, or look for adult services. nonPareil Institute, with its unique
methodology, has ‘changed the game’ in creating new
opportunities for people with autism. Dan Selec, software developer and father to an
autistic teenage son, started nonPareil at his kitchen table four
years ago with just a handful of students. Today there is great demand for places at nonPareil
Institute in Texas, with 150 students currently in the program and over 1,000 who have applied for admission.
nP has been
featured in numerous reports and programs including: Huffington Post, NPR, CNN, and NBC’s
Nightly News http://whatsnext.blogs.cnn.com/2013/07/12/creating-a-school-for-autistic-adults-one-student-at-a-time/?iref=allsearchTo see the impact that nP is having on its
Crewmembers lives, be sure to watch this
quick video http://programminghope.com/videos/336/?fb_ref=widgetWhat happened at our game programming camp?
It was evident from hosting our two-day gaming programming
camp in March, that nonPareil Institute needs to expand to the Northwest. Even with
minimal outreach, we received multiple camp applications and numerous inquiries
(unsurprising since Oregon has
one of the highest autism rates in the America for children ages 6-17) http://graphics.latimes.com/usmap-autism-rates-state/
The
outcome was that our camp was a big hit! See
us in the Newberg Graphic http://portlandtribune.com/nbg/142-news/215815-75586-game-programming-camp-for-autistic-adults-a-hitThe students loved interacting
with the founder of the program Dan Selec, who
came out from Texas to teach the camp, along with two of his amazing autistic
staff trainers, “I love feeling part of something so great, I guess it’s that
sense of community.” 
Everyone was highly engaged with
the material and the students left feeling accepted, confident, and with a new
sense of purpose. The feeling of accomplishment could be seen in many of the
students’ testimonials, “I can’t wait to have more experiences like this.”Parents and families equally
left feeling excited and hopeful for the future, “This was a wonderful
opportunity for my son. I have absolutely no regrets…I love seeing
opportunities out there for older children with autism. This is where the
support for them starts to fall apart and to see the possibilities was truly
exciting. Thank you!”
Thanks to all who helped out, particularly
the mentors and volunteers, “Witnessing the creativity, social
networking, and the overall community nonPareil fosters was truly amazing. They
are leading a movement in understanding the way (individuals) with autism
learn…”Overall,
we had an awesome time and it was
great seeing everyone come together to support this important cause – let’s keep the momentum going!

As
mentioned previously, we need to raise $10,000 in donations to
host a Programming Hope Portland Event. Beyond the event, we hope to raise a further $160,000 to open a local
office and then generate enough funds to open a permanent Portland location.

area, so we really need your help! Please share with all your friends and contacts – this will greatly increase our chances of making this vision
a reality.

Institute founders.

and above in giving their time and expertise.

camp.

story:
Tell me and I forget.

Show me and I remember.
Let me do and I understand.
                               - Confucius

Short Summary

There are over 10,000 entrepreneurship classrooms in the US, reaching over half a million students, but did you know that the vast majority of educators are teaching entrepreneurship from a textbook, rather than letting students experience it for themselves?   

Teaching entrepreneurship should be a lot less like teaching accounting (theory based) and a lot more like teaching basketball (hands on practice).  

My name is Diana Kander. I am an entrepre.nerd and a Senior Fellow at the Kauffman Foundation.  I've written a novel about the trials and tribulations of starting a business and created an accompanying curriculum to get students out of the classroom to experience launching a new venture for themselves.  

The book, All In Startup, takes place at the World Series of Poker and has more sexual tension than any business book you've ever read (meaning students will actually read it).  AND STUDENTS LOVE IT.  But don't take my word for it...see for yourself:


And the curriculum is all about getting students out of the classroom to experience what entrepreneurship is like, even if they don't have an idea they want to pursue. 

Here are some sample student reactions to the curriculum:

Kara:

"For an activity as simple as handing dollar bills to random strangers, the challenge opened my eyes to the value of connecting with others. Even with all of the preparation I made beforehand, approaching people and convincing them to accept my gift was plain awkward. Just this one challenge has taught me that the hardest part of succeeding in business can be communicating with the potential targets of your product or service—the customers. By handing out free money, I wasn’t trying to sell anything, rather just aiming to complete my mission. I had to deal with people who were skeptical of my giving, some who kindly turned down the money, and others who flat-out ignored me. But if I were an entrepreneur trying to attract customers, I would have to deal with similar interactions.  Never before did I think of connecting with customers as being the most integral part to building a business. Frankly, my perspective has been flipped around and I’m thrilled to experience more through the challenges to come."

Sarah: 

“Simulating the beginning stages of a startup through the exercise taught me more about entrepreneurship than any of my lecture-based classes. I was able to actually practice selling and business techniques, which gave me a tangible understanding of what works and what doesn’t in the startup world.  The exercise was actually fun, and I learned so much. I am looking forward to (and slightly scared again) for the next challenge!"

I'm trying to get the book and curriculum into the hands of each of those 10,000 professors in the hopes that they will use it to introduce experiential education - getting customers, finding problems worth solving, testing assumptions, etc - into their classroom.  

Please help get these materials into as many classrooms as possible and help train the next generation of entrepreneurs with proven methodologies to improve their odds of success.

Entrepreneurs like Tony Hsieh of Zappos and Steve Blank think this novel is an excellent representation of the entrepreneurial experience:

Educators see a lot of value to applying the book and curriculum in the classroom:

“There is seldom a read that when you start it, you can't put it down.  Diana Kander has crafted such an experience that fuses an engaging story of choices, dilemmas, tradeoffs, and problems with the real-world experience of the entrepreneur.  In a narrative that captures the culture and the spirit of an entrepreneur in a worthy tale of swagger, hustle and intuition, the reader will learn the lessons of the "all in" entrepreneur and build a framework to approach their own entrepreneurial pathway.  Before you know it, the lessons framed in the book become your own, to the extent that you will convince yourself you have always known them.  I've concluded that anyone who thinks they may want to take a crack at founding a business, should read "All In" first.”

 -Ted Zoller, Director, Center for Entrepreneurial Studies, University of North Carolina – Chapel Hill

_______________________________________________________________

“This book should be required reading for anybody interested in entrepreneurship, from high school students to experienced entrepreneurs because, in contrast to the multitude of traditional, cookie-cutter textbooks on entrepreneurship, it conveys important concepts, and stages in the entrepreneurial process in an easy and entertaining way.

We're using All In Startup as part of our curriculum at the University of Missouri - Kansas City because this book offers a different way of explaining the elements of a business model, how they work together in a coherent way and how to test the assumptions entrepreneurs make about all aspects of their business.”

 - Dirk Libaers - Professor of Entrepreneurship – University of Missouri - Kansas City

What We Need

If you're an entrepreneur, buy a copy of All In Startup for yourself and your team. 

And, if you are feeling generous, please sponsor a school you care about to receive copies of the book and curriculum. 

If you wish your college taught more about talking to customers and less about writing business plans, support your alma mater by buying copies for a single class.

If you're an entrepreneurship educator, buy a copy for your classroom and I'll work with you to help you implement All In Startup into your existing curriculum. 

100% of the funds raised will either be used to send you perks or to send books and materials to as many educators as we can afford to contact.

Our goal is to get over 1,000 entrepreneurs to sponsor the campaign so that the professors we contact understand that this is a real grassroots effort demonstrating the importance and value of experiential rather than theory based education.

If you have a suggestion for additional perks that would entice you to give, we’re excited to hear your suggestions.

More About the Book and Curriculum:

All In Startup: Coming June 30, 2014 from Wiley. 

If Owen Chase doesn’t come up with a way to turn his company around in the next nine days, he will be forced to shut it down and lay off all of his employees. He has incurred serious debt and his marriage is on shaky ground. Through pure happenstance, Owen finds himself pondering this problem while advancing steadily as a contestant at the World Series of Poker. His Las Vegas path quickly introduces him to Samantha, a beautiful mentor with a revolutionary approach to entrepreneurship. Sam is a fountain of knowledge that may save his company, but her sexual advances might prove too much for Owen’s struggling marriage. 

All In Startup is more than just a novel about eschewing temptation and saving a company. It wraps innovative business principles in a thrilling story about high-stakes poker and reveals the emotional reality of entrepreneurship that goes tragically unmentioned during business school.

All In Startup will introduce you to the latest advances in entrepreneurship, including a new understanding of how to launch a company in a way that dramatically improves its chances of success. The “business plan” curriculum taught in most M.B.A. programs is on the verge of extinction. A new “scientific method” of entrepreneurship built around forming and testing basic assumptions will soon become the standard.

Join Owen on his journey as he discovers and begins to practice a new type of entrepreneurship.

If you want to download a sample of the book, you can do so for free here: https://gum.co/NoHFx  The sample includes the foreword by Steve Blank, Introduction, Chapter List, and First Chapter.

___________________________________________________

The curriculum I've designed is pretty simple.  It gets students out of the classroom to help Owen with his experiments.  They can interview customers in their community to find out if the problem Owen has diagnosed actually exists and whether it's serious enough to warrant a business.  They can also try to sell real customers on Owen's proposed solution or one of hundreds of other solutions.

But this is just one application.  I would welcome help from professors on developing other curriculum applications of All In Startup. 


About Diana

A refugee of the Soviet Union, Diana Kander entered America as an eight-year old resident of subsidized housing in Brooklyn, New York. By the time she was an American citizen, she had perfected her skills as a capitalist – selling flea market goods to grade school classmates at a markup.


Today, Diana is a successful entrepreneur, having founded and sold a number of ventures, and a Senior Fellow at the Ewing Marion Kauffman Foundation, the largest non-profit in the world dedicated to entrepreneurship and education. Diana draws on her experience as a founder, investor, and academic to design and implement curriculum in educational institutions and the private sector. 

A sought out public speaker and writer, Diana has advised startup founders and Fortune 500 executives on her methodology for customer-focused innovation.

Diana lives in Columbia, Missouri with her high school sweetheart/best friend/husband, Jason, and their awesome son True.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Please help us get the word out about this campaign, especially to any entrepreneurship educators you may know.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the message.

Thank you! Thank you! Thank you! For your support!

story:
Welcome

The Trinity School Baja Bound chapter invites you to participate in a life transforming volunteer experience just 90 miles south of San Diego in the southern region of Ensenada, Mexico. Ensenada is a safe and easy drive from the U.S./Mexico border but a world away spiritually, economically and culturally. This region is characterized by both breath-taking beauty and desperate poverty. Baja Bound Trinity School students strive to make an annual trip to Ensenada to participate in the construction of a home for a family among the working poor. Each year a family is selected at random through lottery. However, in order to make the journey and the construction of a new home for a family in need possible adequate funding is a must. Therefore, we need all the help we can get! 

Construction materials are $6975 with additional lodging and travel fees for volunteers at an estimated 14,000 for a team of 15 volunteers. 

Every penny counts!

 

Sincerely,

The Baja Bound Trinity chapter 


Please contact  Kate Thomas at kathryn.thomas14@trinityschoolnyc.org  or Aaron Smithson at  aaronsmithson7@gmail.com with any questions or concerns or visit http://www.bajabound.org for more information...

story:
Hi, my name is Gerald and about 40 years ago, my mom and dad moved from the Bronx to buy their first home in the city of Mount Vernon, New York. We were the first African-American family to own a home on our block. For my parents and the four kids, it was an exciting time and many great memories remain from those years and all the wonderful things we all learned.

Forty years later, much has changed of course, Mount Vernon is now the only major city in the state of New York where a minority represents the majority with African-Americans at about 65% of the population.

Mount Vernon is a city of about 70,000 people and is the third largest city in Westchester County of just more than 900,000 people. Westchester County includes some of our nation’s most affluent communities including many that you may have heard of- Bronxville, Scarsdale, and Pelham.

Unlike those locations, Mount Vernon is known for having a higher crime rate, a higher poverty rate, and a higher unemployment rate, some of the highest in the county and the state.

Mount Vernon has about 9000 students that attend its public schools, 97% of those children are children of color- black or brown and slightly more than 40% of those children live at or below the poverty level.

Most distressing, our children’s science and math test scores confirm that these youngsters will not be prepared to compete for middle-class enabling careers. One current result that speaks strongly to our concerns is reflected in the fact that the high school graduation rate is more than 20% lower than communities within walking distance of Mount Vernon.

Our plans to drive meaningful change include creating/building a technology and science center, an informal learning environment that will provide our children with access to critical resources that have proven to produce better outcomes including greater interest in the sciences, better test performance and better graduation rates.

While we are working very hard to raise the funds to build the 140,000 square foot center, we are also delivering various programs for the children so that they will know of our promise to make their lives and most importantly, their future better. The SECOND program that we are providing is our free 6-Saturday STEM Program for 10th & 11th Grade girls attending any one of the three public high schools in Mount Vernon. The program includes fours Saturday’s in November and two Saturday’s in December. This program will provide an intense learning experience with engaging, supportive learning that includes the young women learning Coding and Entrepreneurship with a chance to win $2,500.00. Here is more about the modules that will be included:

Coding with Alice 2.0

Alice 2.0 is an Object-Oriented Programing (OOP) tool used to engage students in the basic concepts of programing without the need to teach advanced technological semantics of programming. The goal of this course is to introduce students to the basic functions of programing using an Alice 2.0 platform. With its project-oriented, step-by-step instruction, students will easily grasp programming concepts and build confidence in their skills. Students will learn through hands-on projects how to create worlds, insert 3D objects and manipulate those objects in a 3D environment. Themes are utilized to build interest and create a functional storyline, as well as create intractable scenarios in an Alice environment. After weekly class assignments are completed students will create short independent projects which will highlight concepts learned during the weekly assignments.  Independent projects serve a dual purpose which is to implement Alice concepts learned and to inspire individual creativity. Computers will be needed to execute all class assignments. 

Required Equipment: Computer with a separate mouse, will be provided.

Required Textbooks: Gary Shelly, Thomas Cashman, and Charles Herbert (2006), “Alice 2.0 Introductory Concepts and Techniques. ISBN-10: 1-4188-5934-6 and ISBN-13: 978-1-4188-5934-3, will be provided.

Start It UP! Entrepreneurship Fundamentals

Do you dream of starting your own business? Are you creative, innovative and eager to make a difference?

The entrepreneurship class will teach you the fundamentals of running and starting a business – how to recognize an opportunity, identify your target market, finance your business and promote it. As part of the entrepreneurship class you will participate in the NFTE World Series of Innovation.  Working together in teams of at least two (2) and not more than five (5) you will select one of the many Innovation challenges and come up with a new, unique, innovative product or service to address the market niche. Your mission is to demonstrate how the product or service will impact people's lives on a day-to-day basis. Completed submissions are due by November 20, 2014, during Global Entrepreneurship Week. A panel of judges will select the top 10 submissions in each challenge category, each of whom will be given 4 weeks to film and create the commercial for which they provided a story board and script. The two winning teams in each category will receive a prize of $2,000 to share, and a prize of $500 for their school or other non-profit youth serving organization. Winning team members in the Microsoft Mobile App Design and Mobile Game Design categories will each receive a Microsoft Student Productivity Suite (such as Microsoft Office and Student) from Microsoft.

While we have been able to raise some of the money to cover some of the cost, we need help to make it a reality. Every dollar raised with be exclusively used to address the cost of camp that includes all 25 young women from this at-risk, underserved population.

If you are able to give us $25.00 or more and share this with your friends, we will reach our goal, please help us and thank you for your kind consideration!

We invite you to be a part of this important project to improve the lives of more than 9,000 public school students in Mount Vernon, New York. The center will also serve as an invaluable resource available to all children throughout the tri-state region. A detailed business plan, preliminary architectural building designs, and additional information are available at your request. Please see our website for more information about the center and to learn of other ways that you can help us drive change- www.mvtsc.org.

PERKS

In addition to our sincere thanks and appreciation, all that are able to give $25.00 or more will receive our MVTSYCA T-Shirt. For gifts of $250.00 or more, we will add a free 1-year Membership for you, a family member or friend that includes free access and a 15% discount on all products purchased at the center. For gifts of $500.00 or more, we will make the membership and discounts of 20% include up to 4 people. $1,000.00 or more in giving will include all the other perks plus we will also add your name to our granite “Wall of Honor”, where it will remain.

THANK YOU FOR CARING, IT MATTERS!




.
