story:
I believe in secondGo because its vision and intent are clear and humbling, and its executive team magnificently creative and able.

Isabelle Beaumount- Owner, Workplace Futures

_________________________________________________________________________


Our mission

secondGO allows university students to exchange second-hand items while extending educational opportunities through scholarships.


The two problems we are solving

Problem 1: Waste

Busy with exams, last events and getting things wrapped up before leaving university?  Running out of time to deal with everything you will not be able to take home but that cost you money when you arrived? Incoming students will want your second-hand items and we will be here next term, when they arrive at university.

Our idea started when we noticed noticed that, at the end of each academic year, university students waste a lot of second-hand items - bikes, books, electrical devices etc. This happens because leaving and incoming students do not physically meet at university, making the transaction of these items impossible.

secondGO will bridge this gap: our online platform and our June collection and October selling events will allow leaving university students to decide how much money they wish to get back from their items, and incoming students will be able to save money on basic and much-needed items.


Problem 2: Inaccessibility to Education

Many of us can't take education for granted: UNESCO reported in 2012, 94% of students were not able to enrol in tertiary education in sub-Saharan countries. The profits from secondGO sales will be invested into a scholarship scheme enabling students to join universities where secondGO acts. That is why, as a leaving university student, you can decide whether to receive up to 50% of your item revenue or if you want to donate your items. The more you donate, the more scholarships you generate.


The solution: our launch, the £2000 crowd funding and your precious help!


Our model has been recognized and rewarded (UnLtd Try It Award 2013 and Do It Award 2014; semi-finalist idea at the McKinsey Venture Academy 2013 and semi-finalist idea at NACUE Varsity Pitch 2013), We are very confident that we are bridging a very significant gap (just at the University of Cambridge, where we are starting, approximately 330,000 items are wasted every year!) and we have an amazing team of 11 university undergraduate students, graduate students, postdocs and staff, ready to test secondGO for this first time this year. 

Please help us raise £2000 for the launch of secondGO at the University of Cambridge, in June 2014. We have already secured free storage and recruited volunteers who have very kindly agreed to support us during our item collection events, but we still need to fund our logistics, our marketing plan and the development of our website. Your support would enable us to fund:

- Van rental

- Diesel

- PAT testers

- Cardboard boxes

- Rented card terminals

- Extension cords

- Tape

- Flyers and Banners

- Web Development



What if we raise less than £2000?

The wastage of second-hand items owned by university students does not only happen at the University of Cambridge, where we are piloting at selected colleges. Our model has the potential to be scaled up to all colleges in the University of Cambridge and beyond: to your university too! 

Just as much as we can scale up, we can also scale down: if we raise less than £2000, we will just cover less colleges during our launch. 

Please help us help you make a profit from your second-hand items and save money, generating scholarship for students excluded from higher education, and helping the environment at the same time.


  • The premise of secondGO is so simple, yet set to be so effective. As a low-income student myself, I know how essential financial support can be, and secondGO will be able to benefit such a wide range of students


  • Molly Seymour, Arch and Anth student at the University of Cambridge


_________________________________________________________________________

More about our launch and how you can benefit from it

£2000 will allow us to to launch secondGO at six colleges at the University of Cambridge in June 2014: 

-Clare Hall

- Darwin College

- Fitzwilliam College 

and... three more to be announced! Stay tuned and check whether your college will be involved!

You will benefit from secondGO:

  • Because we are university students- we understand what you need and we have shaped secondGO keeping in mind what we wished were available for ourselves too. As a university leaver, you will not have to individually upload each of the second-hand items you wish to sell or to individually manage their storage and postage: we come to your college and we will do all this for you while you enjoy your last weeks at university.
  • Because, if you are an incoming university student, you can save money by buying our second-hand items at a fraction of the price they would cost otherwise. Conveniently! Our selling events will happen at a central venue at the University of Cambridge.
  • Because our second-hand item transactions happen within your university: secondGO is for students just like you. 
  • Because we are doing this with a purpose: to extend your own educational opportunities to students excluded from higher education through the generation of scholarships.

It is all very simple:

During collection days you will be able to dispose your unwanted goods all at once and you will be free to either donate or sell them. 

Selling: 50% for items above £ 20, while generating scholarships.
You can chose to sell your second-hand items or bundle of second-hand items (eg. kettle, plates & cutlery in one bundle) if they are worth £20 or more, and you will have the opportunity to receive up to 50% of the resale value of the item. You will self-price your items and choose the percentage of the resale value (up to 50%) you would like to receive - keeping in mind that the remaining revenue feeds our scholarship scheme. Following  our guidelines for competitive pricing will increase your chance of selling them to incoming university students in the following academic year. 

Donating: contributing to even more scholarships, just as conveniently!
There are items from which we do not expect to make a profit. However, they will trouble you just as much and they will be even stronger drivers for the generation of secondGO scholarships. Why not conveniently leave all your items worth less than £ 20 with us during our collections days?

Buying 

Second-hand items left behind by university leavers in June 2014 will be listed on our website. You will have the opportunity to  check what is available at secondGO before you meet us on our selling days in October 2014. First come, first served: note down the right codes and make sure you come on time for your favourite items!


Other ways you can help secondGO

There is another way to help our crowd-funding campaign: please share our Indiegogo page with your friends, colleagues, collages, departments and universities.  

Finally, secondGO is for YOU: please shape it as much as you can. We would love to hear your feedback and comments and to know about your interest in bringing secondGO to your university at http://secondgo.org..

story:
Hey guys!

So if you know Jared, you probably have an idea that he loves CrossFit, and what he loves more than CrossFit, is James "OPT" Fitzgerald. OPT is pretty much Jared's man crush, but also is the first winner of the CrossFit games and a well respected program designer for many CrossFitters and boxes. OPT leads weekend long seminars to teach CrossFit athletes and coaches how to become better at designing their own program. I have heard Jared mention more than once that he would love to attend one of these seminars, however, because he thinks of others first he has never spent the money on himself to go. 

There is a program design course May 17-19 in Scottsdale, AZ which happens to be Jared's birthday weekend. I know it is short notice, but I was hoping that we could contribute whatever we feel comfortable with to raise the funds to have him attend the seminar. It looks like all the seminars after this one occur outside of the country. The total cost of the seminar is about $2000 which is pretty expensive I know. I also know how much Jared would appreciate this, how it would help him grow personally and professionally, and that basically it would make his life.

Here is a link to the training course in case you are interested:

http://op.optexperience.com/opt-experience-pd-m......

Please keep this quiet as well, hopefully we can make this the best surprise ever!

story:
Who We Are
We are Marian High School--a Catholic, college-preparatory school for young women sponsored by the Sisters, Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary.

We are students, families, faculty, and staff--past, present, and (hopefully) future.

We value human diversity because of (not despite of) our faith and beliefs, and we want our school to reflect this through both their words and their actions.

We are here to raise funds to offer to the Marian High School administration in exchange for:

  • a sustainable professional development plan to train all faculty and staff in diversity and inclusivity;
  • a high-quality diversity club moderated by either a trained staff member or a trained youth advocate where students can feel supported (and offer support) regardless of their sexuality, gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, or ability.

What We Need
 Marian High School relies on student tuition and private donations for funding, and the administration undoubtedly knows that money talks. 

We seek to raise at least $50,000 to offer to Marian High School, provided that the funding goes toward: professional development in diversity and inclusivity for all staff and faculty as well as a student-focused diversity club that provides a safe space, a welcoming community, and a forum for dialogue.  We will offer any funds that are raised by the end of this campaign, regardless of the amount.

Based on calculations made through The Wallace Foundation website, our conservative estimate to sustain an out-of-school program alone is about $10,000 per year. A five-year program, based on this conservative estimate, will be above $50,000. 


Our goal is for these institutional changes to create a school culture where all members (students, faculty, staff, and families) can feel supported, valued, and heard regardless of their sexuality, gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, or ability.

If the Marian administration refuses to open their minds and hearts to join the rest of us in the 21st century, the money will be donated to Affirmations, a local LGBT community center that also offers youth empowerment programming.

Why We Are Here


In June 2014, Barb Webb, who served at Marian High School for nine years as a chemistry teacher and a volleyball coach, discovered the joyful news that she and her partner, Kristen, were pregnant. Ms. Webb informed the Marian administration of her pregnancy in July 2014, asking for a leave of absence in a proactive attempt to remain discreet and to not cause any undue attention to herself, her partner, and their soon-to-be family. In August 2014, the president of Marian High School gave Ms. Webb two options: resign, or we will terminate you. If she had chosen to resign, Ms. Webb would have received health benefits through the end of May 2015 and would have been required to sign a confidentiality agreement.  Essentially, the Marian administration would have paid for her silence.

Barb Webb, however, did not choose to be silent. She chose to take the termination and  to speak out against discrimination.  In doing so, a community of thousands of supporters from across the globe--starting with just one passionate alumna who started a Facebook group--chose to stand with her in solidarity.

We are here to encourage you to stand with us, too, and to stand for equality.

How Marian Can Be the Change

Our hope is for Marian to be a Catholic school that is truly catholic--that is, a school that is inclusive of all people.  We hope for the students to feel valued and supported, regardless of who they are or who they love, and we want the veils of shame and secrecy of being LGBTQ to be lifted.

With your help, we can provide the Marian High School administration with the funding and resources necessary to promote a culture of inclusion that values human diversity.

For Marian to accept the funding to create positive, institutional change is far from radical. Rather, it simply would be living up to the mission of the school to “enable young women to value human diversity and live responsible lives of leadership and action“ and to the mission of the Sisters, Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary “to bringing about the dream of God on planet Earth through respect for, nurturing of and promoting liberation and well-being of all persons and all of nature as God’s good creation.”

We urge Marian to be the change (and for you to help us), because we are part of and allies to the LGBTQ community, because we love someone who is, because we acknowledge reality, and because it is time.

Where We Go Next If...
The Marian administration may wish to continue their culture of silence, shame, and secrecy. They, indeed, may refuse to take the money we raise and instead maintain the discriminatory and outdated status quo. If Marian chooses to pass up an incredible opportunity to be the change, all money raised will be given to Affirmations, the largest LGBT community organization in the state of Michigan.  

When Your Voice Is What You Can Give

If you are unable to make a monetary donation, we appreciate your support in the form of spreading the good word.
  • Join our Facebook Group I Stand With Barb Webb.
  • Visit our website at standwithbarb.com (which includes links to all media coverage of Barb Webb’s dismissal and the movement).
  • Sign our petition on Change.org encouraging Marian to be the change we hope to achieve through this campaign,
  • Follow us on Instagram and Twitter @standwbarbwebb
  • Share! Share! Share! And don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

In peace and solidarity,
The Organizers


**Please note! We are NOT a formal non-profit and are not employed by Marian High School. Any funds donated to this campaign are not eligible for a tax donation. A portion of funds raised will be used to offset costs for the perks, cover all fees that are incurred by indiegogo and credit card processing as well as some additional operating costs, including the the upkeep of our website.**
story_txt:
Who We Are
We are Marian High School--a Catholic, college-preparatory school for young women sponsored by the Sisters, Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary. 
We are students, families, faculty, and staff--past, present, and (hopefully) future.
We value human diversity because of (not despite of) our faith and beliefs, and we want our school to reflect this through both their words and their actions.
We are here to raise funds to offer to the Marian High School administration in exchange for:
a sustainable professional development plan to train all faculty and staff in diversity and inclusivity;
a high-quality diversity club moderated by either a trained staff member or a trained youth advocate where students can feel supported (and offer support) regardless of their sexuality, gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, or ability.
What We Need
Marian High School relies on student tuition and private donations for funding, and the administration undoubtedly knows that money talks. 
We seek to raise at least $50,000 to offer to Marian High School, provided that the funding goes toward: professional development in diversity and inclusivity for all staff and faculty as well as a student-focused diversity club that provides a safe space, a welcoming community, and a forum for dialogue.  We will offer any funds that are raised by the end of this campaign, regardless of the amount.Based on calculations made through The Wallace Foundation website, our conservative estimate to sustain an out-of-school program alone is about $10,000 per year. A five-year program, based on this conservative estimate, will be above $50,000. Our goal is for these institutional changes to create a school culture where all members (students, faculty, staff, and families) can feel supported, valued, and heard regardless of their sexuality, gender, race, ethnicity, socioeconomic status, or ability.
If the Marian administration refuses to open their minds and hearts to join the rest of us in the 21st century, the money will be donated to Affirmations, a local LGBT community center that also offers youth empowerment programming.
Why We Are HereIn June 2014, Barb Webb, who served at Marian High School for nine years as a chemistry teacher and a volleyball coach, discovered the joyful news that she and her partner, Kristen, were pregnant. Ms. Webb informed the Marian administration of her pregnancy in July 2014, asking for a leave of absence in a proactive attempt to remain discreet and to not cause any undue attention to herself, her partner, and their soon-to-be family. In August 2014, the president of Marian High School gave Ms. Webb two options: resign, or we will terminate you. If she had chosen to resign, Ms. Webb would have received health benefits through the end of May 2015 and would have been required to sign a confidentiality agreement.  Essentially, the Marian administration would have paid for her silence.Barb Webb, however, did not choose to be silent. She chose to take the termination and  to speak out against discrimination.  In doing so, a community of thousands of supporters from across the globe--starting with just one passionate alumna who started a Facebook group--chose to stand with her in solidarity.We are here to encourage you to stand with us, too, and to stand for equality.How Marian Can Be the Change 
Our hope is for Marian to be a Catholic school that is truly catholic--that is, a school that is inclusive of all people.  We hope for the students to feel valued and supported, regardless of who they are or who they love, and we want the veils of shame and secrecy of being LGBTQ to be lifted. 
With your help, we can provide the Marian High School administration with the funding and resources necessary to promote a culture of inclusion that values human diversity.
For Marian to accept the funding to create positive, institutional change is far from radical. Rather, it simply would be living up to the mission of the school to “enable young women to value human diversity and live responsible lives of leadership and action“ and to the mission of the Sisters, Servants of the Immaculate Heart of Mary “to bringing about the dream of God on planet Earth through respect for, nurturing of and promoting liberation and well-being of all persons and all of nature as God’s good creation.”
We urge Marian to be the change (and for you to help us), because we are part of and allies to the LGBTQ community, because we love someone who is, because we acknowledge reality, and because it is time.
Where We Go Next If...The Marian administration may wish to continue their culture of silence, shame, and secrecy. They, indeed, may refuse to take the money we raise and instead maintain the discriminatory and outdated status quo. If Marian chooses to pass up an incredible opportunity to be the change, all money raised will be given to Affirmations, the largest LGBT community organization in the state of Michigan.  When Your Voice Is What You Can Give If you are unable to make a monetary donation, we appreciate your support in the form of spreading the good word. 
Join our Facebook Group I Stand With Barb Webb.
Visit our website at standwithbarb.com (which includes links to all media coverage of Barb Webb’s dismissal and the movement).

Sign our petition on Change.org encouraging Marian to be the change we hope to achieve through this campaign,
Follow us on Instagram and Twitter @standwbarbwebb 
Share! Share! Share! And don’t forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!
In peace and solidarity,The Organizers**Please note! We are NOT a formal non-profit and are not employed by Marian High School. Any funds donated to this campaign are not eligible for a tax donation. A portion of funds raised will be used to offset costs for the perks, cover all fees that are incurred by indiegogo and credit card processing as well as some additional operating costs, including the the upkeep of our website.**

story:
Spread the Word !Visit our site : infino.me
Like our Facebook page

The Movement

infinome is a citizen science experiment to help people lose weight, feel better, and live longer. By bringing together genetic, health, fitness, and diet data, we can better understand the interactions between genetics and lifestyle and finally answer the nature/nurture debate on why people get obese.

We are scientists who want to turn the wealth of personal genomic, tracking and health data now available into high impact research on how genes and lifestyle drive obesity--a leading risk factor for heart disease, the number one killer.

This campaign will fund the development and design work needed to integrate these data into a freely accessible analytics platform to help everyone understand how their genetic risks and lifestyle choices impact their health.



Goals

We need your help to turn our research strategy and vision into a real service! We need some money to keep the lights on while we finish our prototype. If we raise enough money, we will expand our development team with additional engineers. The more money we raise, the faster this happens! We’re using a flexible funding option so we can push as far as we can.

We’ve been prototyping our system for the last year as a side project. So far, we have tools that will enable users to visualize their genomic risks for common preventable diseases. We will finish these tools as a first priority. Once this work is done, we will expand to do novel research on collected sensor data and supporting a full range of sensor APIs.

 

The Vision

About 75% of the variability in body mass index (BMI)--a key health indicator--is due to genetics, but the known genetic variants account for only about 17% of variance. We hope to identify part of this ‘missing heritability’ using the rich data available from users of personal genome services and self-tracking devices. Unlike traditional studies, these datasets provide detailed longitudinal information about fitness, health and diet. This multidimensional data can help us find interactions that aren’t feasible for scientists in academia to test and make novel contributions to the study of obesity genetics. This is a revolutionary new approach to genomics.


Other Ways You Can Help

We need data to make this work. Genetic studies often require samples from tens of thousands of individuals. With detailed, multidimensional phenotypic data from self-tracking devices, we can begin to identify genetic and gene-lifestyle effects in smaller samples, but we still need to establish a user base.

Even if you can’t contribute financially, you can still contribute the vital data we need. If you track your activity or health metrics or have consumer genetic data, register at infino.me and we’ll send an invitation when we are ready to start integrating your data. You’ll also have an opportunity to tell us about the devices you use, which will help us prioritize API integration so we can support as many users as quickly as possible.

Learn more about self-tracking devices on our site.

Finally, you can help spread the word and connect with us on Facebook/infino.me or @infinome.



The Science of Age-Related Diseases

Want to learn more about the science of diabetes, obesity, aging, and sleep? Check out this lecture that the founder gave at the Longevity and Genetics conference hosted by the Lifespan Society of British Columbia.




Who We Are

CLINTON MIELKE, PHD

My family has a strong genetic predisposition to obesity, diabetes, and heart disease, and I've suffered severe obesity and sleep problems for most of my life. I was sick of being sick, so I left my astronomy career behind and completed my PhD research at the Mayo Clinic on metabolic syndrome. I learned enough about my metabolism to get healthy, but it was a long journey of taking my life back.

I have devoted my life to solving this medical crisis so no one else has to be limited by their health. Infinome is my fight for the millions of people still struggling to get healthy.

ROELAND HANCOCK, PHD

I am a cognitive neuroscientist and software developer. My current research focuses on identifying genetic factors underlying individual differences in language processing and brain organization and developing novel, network-based approaches to big data analysis. I'm excited by the potential for Infinome to change the way we do genetic association studies and address new questions that are currently too difficult and costly to study.

story:
Hello! My name is Robyn Tribuzi...

...and I've been the dance director at San Mateo High School in California's Bay Area for 13 years, and an educator for nearly 35 years. Teaching dance has allowed me to take my lifelong passion for the performing arts and use it to help change and shape the lives of my many students, and one of the most wonderful ways in which I'm able to achieve that is by taking a large group of high school dancers (102 this trip!) to New York City every other year. My kids get the opportunity to dance with Broadway pros, chat with Tony Award winners, see the season's most exciting new shows, and experience firsthand what it means to pursue a professional career in the arts.

This year, I need some extra help to make this once-in-a-lifetime trip a reality for my students. And that's where you come in!

What We Need

New York is vibrant! New York is thrilling! New York is...really, really expensive. Our five day, four night trip costs $1,800 per person. This price includes:

  • Round-trip airfare from San Francisco to NYC, transportation to and from JFK/Newark, and a Metro Card
  • 4 nights' accommodations near Times Square
  • Tickets to 3 Broadway shows (Honeymoon in Vegas, On the Town, and Aladdin, plus an after-show talkback with the cast of Aladdin) and 1 Off-Broadway show (Hamilton)
  • 4 breakfasts and dinners
  • A private dance class at Steps, two private dance classes with Broadway performers from Aladdin and On the Town, plus an optional workshop at the Hip Hop Conservatory
  • Admission to/guides for various Manhattan landmarks, such as the "Top of the Rock" Observation Area, Lincoln Center, the Staten Island Ferry, Ground Zero and the 9/11 Museum, the Apollo Theater, and a tour of the Upper West Side, including Central Park, St. John the Divine, Columbia University, and Harlem

Many of my students come from low-income homes, and as such, can't afford the full price of the trip. In these cases, I ask them to pay whatever they can, and I cover the rest of their trip myself out of my limited yearly budget. In addition, I also cover the cost of all checked airline bags ($25 per bag, per person, per flight; yikes!), open classes for all my kids at Broadway Dance Center, a private group Pilates session, and the all-important San Mateo High School NYC Trip scarf.

All told, we need upwards of $20,000 to make this year's trip happen.

We have small fundraisers throughout the year to try and make up the difference, but this time the amount is too great for us to get by on gift-wrap and cookie dough alone.

What You Get

Everyone who contributes $25 or more to our campaign can choose to be thanked in the program of our 2015 Spring dance concert. At higher levels, donators can receive items like a 4x6 suitable-for-framing picture of this year's group, and a hand-written thank you note from one of the students.

As an extra incentive for San Mateo High School parents to donate, I'm offering Gold Level tickets to our 2015 Spring dance concert as a reward at the $250-and-above levels. Our dance shows are open seating, which means securing those front-and-center seats from which to proudly watch your baby get their groove on can be a time-consuming hassle. But with Gold Level tickets in your hand, you're guaranteed a fabulous seat, even if you don't swan in until the second before the lights dim.

And for those of you with deep pockets and an even deeper love of Broadway, we've got a personalized thank you video just for you from James Monroe Iglehart, the Tony Award winning star of Disney's ALADDIN, at the $1,000 level!

A Life-Changing Opportunity

Many of my students go on to successfully pursue careers in dance and theatre, but even those who don't have told me that attending the New York trip had a profound influence on their lives. For a lot kids, it's their first major trip away from home. For others, it's the deciding factor in where they want to go to college, or what roles performance and the arts are going to play in their adult lives. No matter the path they choose, the chance to experience Manhattan's verve and vitality at this formative stage in their lives is not something they'll soon forget.

Boost the Signal!

If you haven't got any cash to spare at the moment, don't worry! You can still help! Crowdfunding doesn't really work without, y'know, the crowd, so please, please share this link with everyone you know! Post it on Twitter, put it up on Facebook, email it to your family; every pair of eyes that scans this page increases the chances of us being able to make this trip a reality for every single child that wants to attend.

Thank you so much for looking over our campaign!

    Boost the Signal! If you haven't got any cash to spare at the moment, don't worry! You can still help! Crowdfunding doesn't really work without, y'know, the crowd, so please, please share this link with everyone you know! Post it on Twitter, put it up on Facebook, email it to your family; every pair of eyes that scans this page increases the chances of us being able to make this trip a reality for every single child that wants to attend.
Thank you so much for looking over our campaign!

story:
Short Summary

Tufaan Entertainment is a student-led non-profit entertainment company at Northwestern University. Our mission is to raise awareness of South Asian culture in the US and promote education through the arts abroad by hosting a national South Asian dance competition every year. Every year we invite 10 of best collegiate dance teams from across the country to compete in Chicago and donate 100% of the proceeds to a beneficiary that supports education and the arts in India. For the past three years, we have supported Shanti Bhavan Children's Project and over this time, we have donated over $40,000 to them.  Shanti Bhavan is a k-12 boarding school in India that provides a world-class liberal arts education, completely free of cost, to some of India's most socioeconomically disadvantaged children. They provide everything from shelter to school supplies and focus on holistic learning so that their students are one day able to enter the workforce as confident and capable individuals, thus alleviating the cycle of poverty that their families have faced for generations before them.


What We Need & What You Get

Although running Tufaan does cost us nearly $10,000 every year, we recognize that the scale of our donation to Shanti Bhavan would not be possible without running our dance competition. 100% of all ticket sales from the show every year are donated directly to Shanti Bhavan. 

Last year, we decided that we wanted to increase our annual donation to Shanti Bhavan so we set up a separate fundraiser with the sole purpose of raising money strictly for them. 100% of the money raised through this campaign will be sent directly to Shanti Bhavan! We were able to successfully fundraise $2,000 through this campaign last year and we hope to surpass that amount this year. 

Perks for donating:

  • All donations at tax deductible because Tufaan is a certified 501c3 non-profit under Northwestern
  • $25-$49 A personalized thank you card from a Tufaan Board Member
  • $50-$99 A personalized thank you card from a Shanti Bhavan student
  • $100< Name in the Tufaan 2015 program

The Impact

Shanti Bhavan is a unique institution serving children from India’s lowest caste - The Dalits or “untouchables” - who are routinely victims of social segregation and discrimination. These children live on 50 cents a day, often in abusive situations. Shanti Bhavan strives to build a future for these children beyond the limitations of their social class. The programs at Shanti Bhavan address the holistic development of a child; their multi-faceted approach focuses on emotional health, intellectual stimulation, physical fitness, artistic expression, and cognitive growth, carefully developed within a strong moral foundation.

Teachers and volunteers follow a rigorous and comprehensive curriculum, providing children a competitive English-medium education in sciences, mathematics, languages, business and the arts, which prepares Shanti Bhavan Students for advanced studies. All 14 students from the school’s first graduation class of 2010 were accepted into top colleges in Bangalore, all of which are considered among the best universities in India.

Shanti Bhavan creates immediate benefits to both its children and the private sector in India. Having received high levels of academic achievement and unparalleled success, its children will take a significant leap in their personal and professional lives, allowing for a permanent break from the cycle of poverty. Graduates of the program will support their households and contribute to the development of their communities in long-term and self-sustaining ways.

In the private sector, Shanti Bhavan immediately provides an avenue for corporations to exercise social responsibility through support of projects, and extends a proven education model to poor communities. In the long term, replication of this model will contribute high educated, productive employees to India, who are able to thrive both domestically and internationally.

The Shanti Bhavan model, if scaled, offers an opportunity for the private sector to achieve what the public sector has yet been unable to accomplish - the dream of a socially equitable society and a vibrant economy through the creation of meaningful opportunities for historically deprived communities in India. We invite you to join is in this endeavor.

The contributions of valued sponsors like you will help us encourage awareness and appreciation of South Asian culture through a national dance competition, allowing all profit that we are able to raise from the event to be donated to Shanti Bhavan to support their commendable cause.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are grateful for any size donation. If you are unable to make a monetary donation, please share our campaign with friends and family. Here are some other things you can do to help:

  • Check out our website at http://www.tufaanentertainment.com/home.html
  • Like us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/tufaanentertainment?ref=br_tf
  • Attend our show on March 21st, 2015 in Cahn Auditorium at Northwestern University
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the word!

Tufaan Entertainment and Shanti Bhavan thank you for your help!

Tufaan Entertainment and Shanti Bhavan thank you for your help!

story:
We recently visited three of the refugee camps in Bar Elias, Lebanon. A 25km drive from the Syrian border. Most of the children here have no access to education. Today approximately 1.600,000 refugees live in informal settlements in Lebanon. 

The Syrian border is 25 km from the camp pictured, behind the mountains.

The majority fled Syria when their homes were attacked or taken by radical groups. They left with nothing but the clothes they were wearing. Before they lived with dignity, they worked, children went to school, they had food and toys. They had life chances and life hopes. Those possibilities of a life have been taken away from them. Many do not have any support from the established NGO's and most have no access basic everyday things. The average family has approximately 6 children from ages 1 to 12.

Remarks by António Guterres, United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, 26 February 2015

"With the refugee situation growing more protracted and more desperate, almost two million Syrian refugees under 18 risk becoming a lost generation. And many of the over 100,000 refugee children born in exile could face the risk of statelessness. If this is not properly addressed, this crisis-in-the-making could have huge consequences for the future, not only of Syria but also of the region.

As humanitarian resources dwindle, abandoning refugees to hopelessness only exposes them to even greater suffering, exploitation and dangerous abuse. Abandoning their hosts to manage the situation on their own could result in serious regional destabilization, and more security concerns elsewhere in the world."





This humanitarian crisis is well documented in different media outlets, and discussed by politicians on a daily basis. Unfortunately, there is more talking than action. More symbolic politics than solutions. This project is an attempt to create one concrete solution that contributes to solve part of the problem: the kids and their possibilities to get an education.

How can you help?
The AUB ( American University Beirut) has developed an affordable, modular, portable school that can be built in 5 days. The idea is that the school can be transported back to Syria when the conflict ends. Each school costs $40.000, can hold up to 400 children and employ up to 20 teachers and workers. We visited 3 of the operating schools and we were amazed by the efficiency of these structures. The families are grateful that the children can continue their education. “We live in this misery but at least, our children can study and aspire to a better life in the future. We don’t want them to be a totally lost generation, full of trauma and hate".


(diagram of modular system of the schools)

(example of a completed school in a settlement)

(classroom)


We hope you can contribute and help us do something about the situation!

The donation money will be delivered to the AUB group that has designed and built the 3 schools we visited. In addition we would like to help #catalyticaction implement a playground in the school built with this fund.

For more info about the schools: https://www.aub.edu.lb/ifi/public_policy/pal_camps/Documents/research_reports/20140224ifi_pc_unrwa.pdf

story:
Statement of Need

Major obstacles face Gazans in terms of obtaining updated books and resources. According to a survey conducted by the Palestinian Museum in 2016, Gaza contains a small number of municipal public libraries distributed throughout the strip. The number of books in these libraries is limited. This survey shows that Gaza had 41 libraries of which 21 were closed and 7 were thoroughly destroyed. Rafah, Khan Younis, Deir Albalah, Gaza, North Gaza; these are major cities in Gaza Strip and each contains one public library except for Gaza city which has 2.The majority of books, which are in foreign languages that Gazans don’t know, are merely donations. Moreover, library staff can not travel abroad to purchase books for display in the libraries, due to the Israeli blockade. The sum of books in major libraries accounts to 70000; such a number does not cater to the needs of 1, 800 million Gazans.


Objectives

The project aims at achieving the following objectives:

Renting a place for opening a public library. 

Establishing a nonprofit library in a strategic location that all Gazans can reach. 

Purchasing adequate equipment, devices and furniture for the library. 

Purchasing updated books, references and resources in a variety of subjects.

Training library staff to enable them to respond to the needs of Gazans. 

Making connections with local and universal libraries so as to establish a network of researchers and cultural activists that work on the development of literacy all over Palestine and the world.

Increasing the library hours in the strip, as it is known that major libraries close at 3:00 pm.


Clientele 

This project targets Gazans whether young or old. It specifically aims at helping academic activists, students, researchers to have a suitable environment for growing their intellect and skills.


Resources Needed

Personnel: four librarians, one receptionist

Facilities: 2-floors building, 350 m 

Equipment: 6 PC, LCD, furniture (shelves, tables and chairs, study desks), books and references.

Notice:

Books can be sent to this address:

Mosab Abu Toha 

Gaza-Palestine 
Israel

Zip code: 0097

Phone number: 00972592213114

لمحة حول المشروع

سنُنشأ في غزة مكتبة عامة تكون بمثابة مركزٍ ثقافي يقصده الناس لتعميق إدراكهم وتطوير مهاراتهم الفنية وزيادة الوعي لديهم، فالمكتبة توفر مكانًا آمنًا  للصغار والكبار على حد سواء ليجتمعوا فيه ويتبادلوا الأفكار والتجارب فيما بينهم. سيتم تنظيم ندوات واستدعاء ضيوف بارزين ليلقوا محاضرات كما سيتم الترتيب لأنشطة مختلفة. ستضم المكتبة عدة أقسام، من بينها قسم إعارة الكتب باللغة الانجليزية والعربية وأماكن للمطالعة والدراسة وقاعة اجتماعات للمشاركين، عدا عن قسم الحاسوب والدوريات الإلكترونية، مما يتيح للطلبة والباحثين البحث عن مصادر هامة.

الأهداف

تتلخص أهداف المشورع بما يلي:

1-استئجار مكان يصلح أن يكون مكتبة عامة.

2-إنشاء مكتبة غير ربحية في موقع استراتيجي يسهل لجميع سكان غزة الوصول إليه.

3-شراء معدات وأجهزة وتأثيث المكتبة لتكون صالحة للاستعمال.

4-شراء كتب ومراجع ومصادر حديثة في مختلف المواضيع.

5-تدريب موظفي المكتبة ليكونوا على أتم استعداد لتلبية احتياجات المشتركين.

6-إنشاء علاقات مع المكتبات المحلية والعالمية وذلك من أجل تأسيس شبكة من الباحثين والقيام بأنشطة ثقافية من شأنها تطوير المجالات المعرفية في فلسطين ومناطق أخرى من العالم.

7-زيادة ساعات دوام المكتبة في غزة، وذلك لأن مكتبات القطاع تغلق أبوابها الساعة الثالثة عصرًا.

الأساليب

1-جمع التبرعات لاستئجار مكان من شأنه أن يكون نقطة تلاقي وتنظيم أنشطة ثقافية واجتماعات وندوات.

2-تطوير برنامج تدريب موظفي المكتبة كي يتمكنوا من تلبية احتياجات زوار المكتبة.

3-جمع التبرعات لشراء المعدات الالكترونية والأثاث بالإضافة إلى الكتب والمصادر باللغتين العربية والإنجليزية.

4-جمع تبرعات (كتب).

موضوعات الكتب

أدب، وسياسة، وعلم نفس، وعلم اجتماع، وفلسفة، وتاريخ، وديانات، وكتب أطفال وعلوم، وطب

بإمكانكم ارسال الكتب ال العنوان التالي
Mosab Abu Toha 

Gaza-Palestine 
Israel

Zip code: 0097

Phone number: 00972592213114

story:
Our Story

The Savannah Victorian Society was founded about 1968 and rooted in the desire to save historic buildings which were being threatened in Savannah at that time. Savannah had a Chartered Chapter of the Victorian Society in America (VSA) until 1994.  The VSA is a national non-profit organization devoted to the social and cultural history of the United States from 1837 to 1917. Savannah had the honor of hosting an annual meeting of the Victorian Society in America in 1976, and in 1993 the VSA visited Savannah again when the meeting was held at Jekyll Island. Since the Historic Savannah Foundation (http://www.myhsf.org/) already does a fantastic job of preserving our historic districts and buildings, the Savannah Victorian Society will focus on the protection, understanding, and enjoyment of our nineteenth century heritage with a special emphasis on ornamental horticulture.

 

The Impact


With the continuing interest in Victoriana, and with Savannah's wealth of Victorian architecture and its important 19th century history, the Savannah Victorian Society (SVS) will help to connect people with this interest and knowledge. Some ideas for SVS programs are lectures, field trips, movies, performing arts, and social events. The SVS would like to regain its position as an official chartered chapter of the Victorian Society in America which is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization. The Savannah Victorian Society, upon induction as a chartered chapter will share this non-profit status. Please see http://www.victoriansociety.org for more information about the VSA and the benefits of membership. The city of Savannah and the region will benefit because of the additional exposure and attention resulting from our status as a chartered chapter. Currently there are no chartered chapters of the VSA anywhere in the southeast.


What We Need & What You Get

We will be holding a reception on Sunday 4-3-2011 @6PM. Please attend! It will be held at the historic Kennedy Pharmacy Building at the S/W corner of Broughton and Habersham Street in Downtown Savannah, Georgia, USA.  Any help you can offer with this event would be greatly appreciated!  We invite you to join our local chapter and hope you will also consider membership in the VSA. In order to regain our charter with the national organization, we need to create a signed petition of at least 25 individuals who pledge to join the VSA - Individual $55, family $65, student $35. (A chartered chapter of the VSA requires this only one time, at inauguration. After the first year only board members are required to belong to the national organization.) You may use this site to make your pledge which will allow us to more quickly gauge interest. Or you may bring a check made out to "The Victorian Society in America" to the meeting on 4-3-2011.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this campaign with your friends and business associates so that we may obtain our goal of  a signed petition of at least 25 members of the VSA & SVS in order for us to regain our chartered chapter status. If you are interested in volunteering your time within the organization, please let us know. A new video of Victorian architecture in Savannah made especially for this web site and for future use would be very helpful. Thank You so much for reading. See you on 4-3-2011 @ 6PM! Send questions to victoriansocietyinsavannah@gmail.com

story:
Our Story

Hi. I'm Kim. I have a Master's Degree in Clinical Psychology and a strong passion for working with children. For over 10 years, I have enjoyed the experience of working with preschool age children in various settings.  I have volunteered in child care centers, for Big Brothers/Big Sisters, and in centers for children with autism. I have worked in facilities for children coaching non-competetive gymnastics, karate, sports, and dance for 7 years. I am very playful, open, and loving and am a magnet for 2-5 year olds. In addition to teaching, I have developed curriculum, and grown numerous programs with my excellent sales and marketing skills. I also gained valuable administration and bookkeeping skills through employment at a CPA firm. I have always wanted to combine my passion for psychology with my passion for children. Finally, I figured out a great plan to do this. I have developed a program that will enhance the social and emotional development of children through play. Specifically, the children will learn skills needed for conflict resolution, stress reduction, anger management, and building empathy. The curriculum will be laid out so each fun activity provides a lesson and time to practice these skills. The parents will know what their little ones are learning, but the children will think they are just playing. These classes will be taught at various private preschools, child care centers, and park districts. The focus will initially be on children from 2-5 years old and will later expand to older children (through colllege) and children with special needs. The plan going forward will be for expansion to several teachers, franchising, and then media involvement.


The Impact

Everyone can benefit from increased awareness and self control. We have all said or done something that we later regret. Often, our instinctive reactions come from a lack of immediately available alternatives. Young children are likely to have a meltdown, tantrum, or to resort to a physical expression of their anger such as hitting. Unless we teach children how to calm themselves, manage their anger, and teach them different responses, we can't expect them to act differently. Increasing empathy and connectedness amongst peers will decrease bullying and create an environment that feels safer and is more suitable for learning.


What We Need & What You Get

There are going to be multiple phases of this business. The first phase will begin with training educators and parents to raise awareness of the way they are disciplining children. It is the goal of this business to shift away from fear and punishment based disciplines and move towards methods of discipline that provide explanations of how to do things correctly(rather than telling children what not to do) and building connectedness that cause an increased desire to please others.

 

 In the second phase, I will purchase the equipment needed to run fun classes for children including a parachute, balls, bubbles, musical instruments, hula hoops, bean bags, scarves, music, etc. A company logo and name will need to be created. Marketing materials such as brochures, business cards, banners, and posters will need to be designed and printed. Storage space will be needed for the equipment (more cost effective than an office!!) and insurance will need to be paid for. One of the great things about this model is that after the initial start up costs, there are very few monthly expenses. This makes it much easier for the business to suceed and expand rapidly.

 

The third phase will focus on widening the impact of this program through added classes, instructors, accomodating more ages, franchising and extending the program to more locations, and using media to spread the information as well.

 

As a thank you for helping me, I will provide you with resources/tips to help reduce your stress, manage your anger, and connect better with your parents/peers/family. Of course, you will also have my neverending gratitude and the satisfaction of having a positive impact on the lives of countless children and families!


Other Ways You Can Help

i would love feedback, ideas, suggestions, etc. Please share my idea with everyone you know and LET'S MAKE IT HAPPEN!! Please leave comments. I will do my best to respond to all of them! I am very excited to embark on this journey with you.

There are going to be multiple phases of this business. The first phase will begin with training educators and parents to raise awareness of the way they are disciplining children. It is the goal of this business to shift away from fear and punishment based disciplines and move towards methods of discipline that provide explanations of how to do things correctly(rather than telling children what not to do) and building connectedness that cause an increased desire to please others.
 
 In the second phase, I will purchase the equipment needed to run fun classes for children including a parachute, balls, bubbles, musical instruments, hula hoops, bean bags, scarves, music, etc. A company logo and name will need to be created. Marketing materials such as brochures, business cards, banners, and posters will need to be designed and printed. Storage space will be needed for the equipment (more cost effective than an office!!) and insurance will need to be paid for. One of the great things about this model is that after the initial start up costs, there are very few monthly expenses. This makes it much easier for the business to suceed and expand rapidly. 
 
The third phase will focus on widening the impact of this program through added classes, instructors, accomodating more ages, franchising and extending the program to more locations, and using media to spread the information as well. 
 
As a thank you for helping me, I will provide you with resources/tips to help reduce your stress, manage your anger, and connect better with your parents/peers/family. Of course, you will also have my neverending gratitude and the satisfaction of having a positive impact on the lives of countless children and families!


Other Ways You Can Help
i would love feedback, ideas, suggestions, etc. Please share my idea with everyone you know and LET'S MAKE IT HAPPEN!! Please leave comments. I will do my best to respond to all of them! I am very excited to embark on this journey with you.

story:
On August 12 six homes in the marginalized community of Las Flores, Dominican Republic were destroyed by a devastating fire. The 6 affected families lost all of what little they had. 

We are friends of these families who can attest to their warmth and hospitality.  Although they live on next to nothing they are the most generous people we have ever met.

More than 20 people have lost everything they owned including: Clothing, Appliances, Furniture, Family photos and Heirlooms.  In this subdeveloped country those living on the margins have no access to house or fire insurance, and thus no means of recovering what's lost.

  • We are looking for donations to help these families rebuild their lives and homes.
  • The money will go directly to the affected families to help with the cost of temporary relocation, replacement of possessions and the reconstruction of their houses. 
  • Estimated rebuilding costs to put roofs over the heads of these families is $12,000 US.  Whatever funds we can raise will at the very least get them on their way to recovery.

Your Impact

With your donations we can help to rebuild these people's lives.  Some of the children have already experienced tragedy losing their mother in the Haiti earthquake of 2010.  Many of the others have little prospects for their futures. Most of the adults are unemployed or work as domestic workers.

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate all donations, large or small. If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still help by spreading the word to your family, friends and co-workers.

Please distribute this link to everyone you know via e-mail, facebook, twitter, or the Indiegogo share tools.

 

El 12 de agosto, seis humildes casas en el marginalizado sector de Las Flores, Santiago, República Dominicana fueron destruídas por un devastador incendio. Las 6 familias afectadas perdieron todo de lo poco que poseían.


Nosotros somos amigos de estas familias, que a pesar de todo mantienen su misma hospitalidad y calor humano hacia con los demás porque a pesar de que subsistían con los mínimos requerimientos posibles, continúan siendo las personas mas generosas que hemos podido conocer.

Mas de 20 personas han perdido todas sus pertenencias: ropa, utensilios caseros y personales, muebles, fotos familiares, etc. Dadas las circunstancias de que nos encontramos en un país en vías de desarrollo, estas personas que viven en situaciones de marginalidad no tienen ningún tipo de acceso a un seguro de casa o en caso de incendio y por ende, ninguna manera de poder recuperar lo perdido.

  • Estamos necesitando de donaciones para ayudar a estas familias reconstruir sus casas y hogares.
  • El dinero irá directamente a las familias afectadas para ayudarles con la manutención de donde temporalmente se están hospedando, para el reemplazo de sus pertenencias perdidas y la reconstrucción de sus hogares.
  • Un monto aproximado de la reconstrucción de estas casas perdidas tiene un valor de US12,000 pero los fondos que se obtengan podrán por lo menos ponerlos en el camino de un avance en su recuperación.


TU IMPACTO.

Con tus donaciones puedes ayudarnos a reconstruir las vidas de estas personas. Algunos de estos niños ya han atravesado por la tragedia de perder a sus madres en el terremoto de Haiti en el 2010. Muchos de los otros tienen pocas esperanzas para su futuro. La gran parte de los adultos están desempleados o desempeñan trabajos domésticos.

OTRAS MANERAS EN LAS QUE PUEDES AYUDAR.

Apreciamos todas las donaciones; mucho o poco. Si no te encuentras en la facilidad de poder hacer donaciones de manera económica, puedes aun ayudar pasando la voz a tus familiares, amigos y compañeros de trabajo.

Por favor, pasa este link a todos tus contactos vía e-mail, facebook, twitter o las herramientas para compartir de Indiegogo.

 

**Algunas personas nos han dicho que tienen dificultad hacer una donaciones dentro de la República Dominicana.  Ahora puedes hacer un deposito directamente a Banco Popular.**

Numero de cuenta: 775980741

Nombre: Jenny Checo

story:
Help us to share MuseumNext with the world

MuseumNext is Europe's big conference on the digital side of museums. This event brings together leading experts from museums and galleries around the world to share their experience of using digital and social media.

In 2011, we filmed the conference for the first time. These films have been freely available for anyone to watch since that event and they have collectively had over 20,000 views (see an example here: http://bit.ly/vvVjjl ). 

These have helped students studying a wide range of related subjects and informed best practice at museums and galleries around the world.

The next conference will take place in Barcelona in May. It will feature over 40 presentations from institutions including TATE, Smithsonian, MoMA, V&A, Victoria and Albert Museum, Van Gogh Museum, Tyne and Wear Museums, Museum Kunstpalast, Science Museum, The National Gallery of Denmark, Stedelijk Museum, Museum aan de Stroom, Museu d'Art Contemporani de Barcelona, Centre de Cultura Contemporània de Barcelona, Dulwich Picture Gallery, Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Museon, Fundació Joan Miró, Museum de Toulouse, Reinwardt Academy, The Acropolis Museum, Manchester Museum, Royal Museums Greenwich and Museum of Australian Democracy at Old Parliament House.

We would like to capture these presentations, and share them online for anyone interested in how museums can best use social and digital media.

What We Need & What You Get

MuseumNext receives no funding and is essentially a grassroots organisation, run by volunteers who are passionate about sharing best practice in the museum sector. We want to raise $10,000 to hire a film crew to capture high quality films of the presentations in a format which is easily shared online.

These films will join the existing film library on http://www.museumnext.org and will be free for anyone to view.

As well as sharing the films of the presentations with the world, we will also capture interviews, tips from experts and behind the scenes footage which we will make exclusively available to those who donate more than $20 to fund the filming.

The Impact

We know that the films of MuseumNext 2011 have been quoted in dissertations, used to convince managers of the value of social media and shared by those who attended the event with colleagues who weren't there.

We believe that sharing the knowledge from our 2012 conference can add to this resource, inspiring museums and galleries around the world to think about 'what's next'.

story:
UPDATE: Two of the six students have to have their full balance paid by March 1st! Help!!!!


Hello, my name is Stephanie Dashiell, and I teach English at Bladensburg High School in Bladensburg, MD.  Every year, my students read Homer's "The Odyssey," and William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet. During spring break, my 9th grade students are required to write a 10 page research paper about Ancient Greece.  Many of them are fascinated with the stories of the Greek gods and goddesses.  Some are awed by the architecture.  And, others love the culture as a whole.  This trip would be the perfect extended lesson for our Greek Mythology unit. They would be able to apply the information they learned for their research paper and acquire more knowledge first hand.  The same is true about the Italy tour.  The students read the entire play Romeo and Juliet by William Shakespeare. To experience the Italian culture first hand would be a dream come true for many of them. The students are so excited that they will be able to visit some of the actual locations from each text.  For example, during our Greek Mythology unit, we learned all about Zeus and Apollo's temple. We will be able to visit both places on ourtour!


Each of the students attending our summer tour come from low income families.  Some even come from single parent homes.  So far, there are 6 students enrolled.  There are three Black males, two Black females, and one Caucasian female.  Two of these students are twins, and their single mother has to fund both of their tour costs.  That is well over $6,000.00!  This is the reason we are working so hard to fund this trip.  There are many other students who would like to attend the trip as well, but their families just cannot afford the trip.  I was very sad to see that my Hispanic students were not able to enroll on our tour.  However, I am optimistic about doing another tour next summer.  Hopefully, they will be able to attend next time. 


I have always wanted my students to have an opportunity to visit Greece and Italy, and now it is here! Thanks to EFTours.com, we will be touring Greece and Italy in June of 2012.  Please find it in your heart to help donate to our trip.  I would hate for students to miss this opportunity because of something as small as money.  Give whatever you can.  Tell a friend.  Encourage them to give.  Play a life changing role in these students' lives.  They will NEVER forget this wonderful experience!  Thank you so much in advance!

 


Here is the url for our trip itinerary:

www.eftours.com/preview-tour.aspx?gt=1162511


Where will your money go?  Well, each student is on a payment plan.  The students are also working to fundraise the money for their trip costs.  Each student has to pay about $3000.  I know that is a lot of money for many of my students' families to pay, but I don't want them to miss out on this wonderful opportunity!  So, however much money this donation page raises will be split equally between the students who are going on the trip and applied to their balance.
