story:
What would you do if you were granted a second chance?

www.StoryProject.org

If the challenges of adolescence wasn't enough, imagine tackling these formative years while navigating poverty, gang violence, and questionable domestic surroundings.  Very often our students choose to drop out of school based on their immediate community's dysfunction and the lack of support and direction from their parents and siblings.  To return to a productive, learning environment is a monumental challenge and when they do, these students take it upon themselves to find their path.  The Story Project offers programs that help them better understand their obstacles and the road ahead by providing tools that decipher their past journey as they chart a new course, one that has a much better chance of pointing them in a much more fruitful and positive direction.

 

The Story Project: Imagine.  Create.  Live.
Change your story / Change your life 

Behind every successful business, businessperson, and individual is a terrific story. From world class entrepreneurs to everyday people, understanding story is credited as the single most important factor in determining innovation and prosperity. People such as Richard Branson, Michael Jordan, and even Thomas Edison have publicly acknowledged storytelling as a device that helped chart their paths.


"The first story I finished was when I was six years old."
J. K. Rowling

So what's the story behind The Story Project?  It's simple: Kids. Students more precisely. Our demographic typically falls under the categories of: Title 1, At-Risk, Under-Served, Middle & High School ages. If you're wondering why, the answer is simple. More obstacles. 

Obstacles are a way of life. In screenwriting, adding an obstacle creates drama; in life, if unprepared, an obstacle can cause disaster. 

Of course life is filled with challenges, they are what help define us as individuals, help us recognize our strengths, and determine our future direction. But what if these benchmarks were mired in conflict from the surrounding community? Imagine charting a childhood where the local language was something other than what your often illiterate parents spoke at home? Or consider trying to navigate your early years while your support system is unfortunately dysfunctional due to alcohol or drugs, or even worse, in and out of jail and prison? This is when learning becomes a secondary responsibility behind survival. Eager young brains starving for guidance are forced to adopt a story of a day-to-day existence. Ambitious dreams are soon replaced with nightmares. A childhood of wonder is soon replaced by a life of fear. With time these young lives are lived moment-to-moment. There is no more ambition, only blame. These once innocent lives are then often adopted into a destructive lifestyle of gang violence and despair.


"There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you."
Maya Angelou

Where do dreams come from and, when unrealized, where do they go? 

There's no excuse in our modern America for young people to have to abandon their hopes and dreams. This is a country forged of innovation and leadership, yet our public school system continues to operate on a sub-par level for a whole host of reasons. Thankfully brilliant educators and forward thinkers are now stepping into the school system with new and creative means of revamping an outdated model of education that struggles to meet its goals. With that in mind, it is The Story Project's mission to supplement current academic programs with a unique storytelling curriculum that encourages students to meet their challenges head on creating all sorts of stories through conventional media they already enjoy. Our programs thrive under the guidance of mentors from the Hollywood community who lend their time and talent to the classroom where they shepherd our students' visions to heights they once never thought possible. 

Our programs are rooted in: documentary and fictional filmmaking, poetry, spoken word, photograhy, murals, screenwriting, and many other means based in the media arts.

"We are the hero of our own story."
Mary McCarthy



The Story Project has served students and communities in Los Angeles as far west as Santa Monica, north to Pacoima, east to Altadena, and south to San Pedro. We also have a model that works outside of L.A. and has been successfully tested in Texas and Maryland. 

Current and Past Schools (partial list):

  • Daniel Freeman Elementary School / Inglewood, CA (in partnership with I Have a Dream - L.A.)
  • Central High School / Mar Vista Gardens Projects / West Los Angeles
  • Boys and Girls Club of Burbank and Greater East Valley
  • Mark Twain Middle School / Venice, CA
  • Boys and Girls Club of Venice, CA
  • Centennial High School / Compton, CA
  • Neighborhood Youth Association / Mar Vista, CA
  • Boys and Girls Club of Austin, Texas
  • Pointers Run Elementary School / Howard County, MD
  • Howard County Public Library - East Columbia Branch, MD


"A boy's story is the best that is ever told."
Charles Dickens

Storytelling. What's the big deal?

Just ask a few of our mentors:

Mark Yamor

Glen Cornish

Chris Pierce

As a wheel is meant to turn, people are born to create.  When we are no longer able, or prevented from meeting our purpose, the mechanism breaks and crumbles. 

"If you want a happy ending, that depends, of course, on where you stop your story."   Orson Welles

Like our young students, our story is still being written. Founded in 1998, The Story Project's tale continues to unfold but, in order to do so, we need your help.

A charity is still very much a business.  Program and operating costs are very much the reality of operating a nonprofit in 2012. We accomplish an enormous amount with the assistance from all sorts of generous people who contribute their time, talent, and money to our organization. Keeping our overhead lean affords us the ability to meet the demands of our classes and students. However, we still need to pay for the basics, which is where you come in. 

Please contribute what you can.  The perks listed are a small "Thank You" for making such a huge impact on another person's life. 

That's our story and we're sticking to it!

Thank you from The Story Project family!

 

 

                                  

Jewelry perks at the Sponsor Levels provided by Bez Ambar, Inc. (www.bezambar.com)

About Bez Ambar

Bez Ambar Inc (previously: Ambar Diamonds) is a jewelry design wholesale
manufacturing company based in Los Angeles, California. It was founded by Bez Ambar in 1980. The commitment to innovation, unique artistry and uncompramised quality of workmanship placed the company at the forefront of traditional and fashion diamond jewelry. The company is engaged in rough diamond trading, cutting, and polishing to fit the specific requirments of each design. Bez Ambar’s innovations include new and unique diamond cuts like the Princess, Blaze and the development of advanced setting techniques such as the Invisible setting, the Boundless and the Micro-Pave. Bez Ambar designs are well known and sought after in the jewelry industry and are privately sold to fine jewelry stores through out the USA and Canada.

                        

Grants and Supporters

You're in good company!  The Story Project is immensely grateful to the generous ongoing financial and in-kind support from our premiere donors:

  • Ted Hartley & Dina Merrill
  • The Annenberg Foundation
  • Sony Pictures
  • The Leo Buscaglia Foundation
  • PMI-LA
  • RKO Pictures
     

Testimonials

  • The students of Central High School are blessed to have access to tools such as critical thinking, self-awareness, communication skills, and media literacy provided generously by staff and mentors of The Story Project.  Through ongoing workshops we are able to gain a broader understanding of the talents and gifts that we ourselves hold, and we are constantly challenged in pushing the boundaries of our self expression to manifest these gifts in ways that will benefit our larger community.  We are grateful for all of the resources, motivation, and opportunities that you continue to provide us. 

- Vitaly, Educator at Central High School, Mar Vista Gardens 

 

  • “...We’re having fun thinking up lines and establishing characters to take part in the story! I can't wait to see what the end product is going to be like!  The most important thing is that we learn from this experience and  grow from The Story Project.

- Whitney Williams, Age 13, Burbank Boys and Girls Club

  • “What can I say about The Story Project? It is the best. ... If anyone is questioning whether the Story Project works, they are wasting theirtime while missing out on a wonderful program.  Hope The Story Project continues to bless kids around the world.”

- Kristine Cabrera, Age 17, Neighborhood Youth Association

 

  • "During a 6 week summer program, The Story Project gave an amazing opportunity to 18 Howard County Middle School students to explore the world of writing through their own creative eye. By the middle of July, these children were hard at work as a team, defining their story's theme and identifying the main problem in their Story Project.  Within their unified effort, they identified the characters, blocked each act, and worked on props and costumes.   It was a thrill to be involved in this empowering experience and to see the excitement in our student's eyes as they shared their productions on Premiere Night with their family and friends."

- Julie Egert, Site Project Coordinator

 

  • I was extremely excited to be involved with The Story Project's East Coast pilot program.

    I thought the entire process itself had a structured curriculum (e.g.,
    reviewing the components of developing a good story), as well as a
    unique organic element to it that allowed for students to fully
    conceptualize the project and get involved from start to finish. I
    appreciated how the shyest student and the outgoing extrovert could
    find themselves equally involved in The Story Project - and both could
    flourish!

    Julie and yourself quickly established a strong rapport with the
    students; instruction was very hands-on and delivered in a friendly
    and welcoming atmosphere.

    Including mentors added a further dimension to the process by having
    these experts share their experiences from the field.

    I look forward to working with you again!

- Carmen Albuerne, Information Specialist & Instructor, Howard County Library  East Columbia Branch, Columbia, MD 21045

 

  • Every week, the students and I look forward expectantly to 3:00, Thursday.  That’s when Todd and Bethany bring us fun activities, brilliant mentors, and involve us in memorable experiences like Peace Jam at Loyola Marymount University. I watch as they bring out the story teller in previously reluctant, unmotivated kids. When kids learn to create stories, you can see that they are learning about themselves and growing in confidence. They really do get inspired!

- Clifton Winnard, Teacher librarian, Mark Twain Middle School, Los Angeles, CA.


  • The Story Project staff and mentors encourage kids' creativity and self confidence.  They motivate the kids to discuss, write and develop their own ideas as well as share them with the group. The Story Project unites the kids in collaborating as a team,pooling their ideas and deciding on a common group theme.  They then work together on an exciting goal, in our case a short film. The result was a memorable and educational experience that allowed the kids to explore many facets of the entertainment arts as well as to grow in self esteem.

- Sherry DeLizia, Creative Arts Director, Boys and Girls Club of Burbank and Greater East Valley.
story_txt:
What would you do if you were granted a second chance?
www.StoryProject.org
If the challenges of adolescence wasn't enough, imagine tackling these formative years while navigating poverty, gang violence, and questionable domestic surroundings.  Very often our students choose to drop out of school based on their immediate community's dysfunction and the lack of support and direction from their parents and siblings.  To return to a productive, learning environment is a monumental challenge and when they do, these students take it upon themselves to find their path.  The Story Project offers programs that help them better understand their obstacles and the road ahead by providing tools that decipher their past journey as they chart a new course, one that has a much better chance of pointing them in a much more fruitful and positive direction.
 

The Story Project: Imagine.  Create.  Live.Change your story / Change your life  

Behind every successful business, businessperson, and individual is a terrific story. From world class entrepreneurs to everyday people, understanding story is credited as the single most important factor in determining innovation and prosperity. People such as Richard Branson, Michael Jordan, and even Thomas Edison have publicly acknowledged storytelling as a device that helped chart their paths. "The first story I finished was when I was six years old." J. K. Rowling So what's the story behind The Story Project?  It's simple: Kids. Students more precisely. Our demographic typically falls under the categories of: Title 1, At-Risk, Under-Served, Middle & High School ages. If you're wondering why, the answer is simple. More obstacles.  Obstacles are a way of life. In screenwriting, adding an obstacle creates drama; in life, if unprepared, an obstacle can cause disaster.  Of course life is filled with challenges, they are what help define us as individuals, help us recognize our strengths, and determine our future direction. But what if these benchmarks were mired in conflict from the surrounding community? Imagine charting a childhood where the local language was something other than what your often illiterate parents spoke at home? Or consider trying to navigate your early years while your support system is unfortunately dysfunctional due to alcohol or drugs, or even worse, in and out of jail and prison? This is when learning becomes a secondary responsibility behind survival. Eager young brains starving for guidance are forced to adopt a story of a day-to-day existence. Ambitious dreams are soon replaced with nightmares. A childhood of wonder is soon replaced by a life of fear. With time these young lives are lived moment-to-moment. There is no more ambition, only blame. These once innocent lives are then often adopted into a destructive lifestyle of gang violence and despair.
"There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you." Maya Angelou Where do dreams come from and, when unrealized, where do they go?  There's no excuse in our modern America for young people to have to abandon their hopes and dreams. This is a country forged of innovation and leadership, yet our public school system continues to operate on a sub-par level for a whole host of reasons. Thankfully brilliant educators and forward thinkers are now stepping into the school system with new and creative means of revamping an outdated model of education that struggles to meet its goals. With that in mind, it is The Story Project's mission to supplement current academic programs with a unique storytelling curriculum that encourages students to meet their challenges head on creating all sorts of stories through conventional media they already enjoy. Our programs thrive under the guidance of mentors from the Hollywood community who lend their time and talent to the classroom where they shepherd our students' visions to heights they once never thought possible.  Our programs are rooted in: documentary and fictional filmmaking, poetry, spoken word, photograhy, murals, screenwriting, and many other means based in the media arts.
"We are the hero of our own story."Mary McCarthy
The Story Project has served students and communities in Los Angeles as far west as Santa Monica, north to Pacoima, east to Altadena, and south to San Pedro. We also have a model that works outside of L.A. and has been successfully tested in Texas and Maryland.  
Current and Past Schools (partial list):

Daniel Freeman Elementary School / Inglewood, CA (in partnership with I Have a Dream - L.A.)
Central High School / Mar Vista Gardens Projects / West Los Angeles
Boys and Girls Club of Burbank and Greater East Valley
Mark Twain Middle School / Venice, CA
Boys and Girls Club of Venice, CA
Centennial High School / Compton, CA
Neighborhood Youth Association / Mar Vista, CA
Boys and Girls Club of Austin, Texas
Pointers Run Elementary School / Howard County, MD
Howard County Public Library - East Columbia Branch, MD
"A boy's story is the best that is ever told." Charles Dickens Storytelling. What's the big deal?
Just ask a few of our mentors:
Mark Yamor
Glen Cornish
Chris Pierce
As a wheel is meant to turn, people are born to create.  When we are no longer able, or prevented from meeting our purpose, the mechanism breaks and crumbles. 
"If you want a happy ending, that depends, of course, on where you stop your story."   Orson Welles Like our young students, our story is still being written. Founded in 1998, The Story Project's tale continues to unfold but, in order to do so, we need your help. A charity is still very much a business.  Program and operating costs are very much the reality of operating a nonprofit in 2012. We accomplish an enormous amount with the assistance from all sorts of generous people who contribute their time, talent, and money to our organization. Keeping our overhead lean affords us the ability to meet the demands of our classes and students. However, we still need to pay for the basics, which is where you come in. 

Please contribute what you can.  The perks listed are a small "Thank You" for making such a huge impact on another person's life.  
That's our story and we're sticking to it!Thank you from The Story Project family!
 
  
                                   

Jewelry perks at the Sponsor Levels provided by Bez Ambar, Inc. (www.bezambar.com)

About Bez Ambar
Bez Ambar Inc (previously: Ambar Diamonds) is a jewelry design wholesalemanufacturing company based in Los Angeles, California. It was founded by Bez Ambar in 1980. The commitment to innovation, unique artistry and uncompramised quality of workmanship placed the company at the forefront of traditional and fashion diamond jewelry. The company is engaged in rough diamond trading, cutting, and polishing to fit the specific requirments of each design. Bez Ambar’s innovations include new and unique diamond cuts like the Princess, Blaze and the development of advanced setting techniques such as the Invisible setting, the Boundless and the Micro-Pave. Bez Ambar designs are well known and sought after in the jewelry industry and are privately sold to fine jewelry stores through out the USA and Canada.
                         
Grants and Supporters
You're in good company!  The Story Project is immensely grateful to the generous ongoing financial and in-kind support from our premiere donors:

Ted Hartley & Dina Merrill
The Annenberg Foundation
Sony Pictures
The Leo Buscaglia Foundation
PMI-LA
RKO Pictures 
Testimonials

The students of Central High School are blessed to have access to tools such as critical thinking, self-awareness, communication skills, and media literacy provided generously by staff and mentors of The Story Project.  Through ongoing workshops we are able to gain a broader understanding of the talents and gifts that we ourselves hold, and we are constantly challenged in pushing the boundaries of our self expression to manifest these gifts in ways that will benefit our larger community.  We are grateful for all of the resources, motivation, and opportunities that you continue to provide us. 
- Vitaly, Educator at Central High School, Mar Vista Gardens 
 

“...We’re having fun thinking up lines and establishing characters to take part in the story! I can't wait to see what the end product is going to be like!  The most important thing is that we learn from this experience and  grow from The Story Project.
- Whitney Williams, Age 13, Burbank Boys and Girls Club

“What can I say about The Story Project? It is the best. ... If anyone is questioning whether the Story Project works, they are wasting theirtime while missing out on a wonderful program.  Hope The Story Project continues to bless kids around the world.”
- Kristine Cabrera, Age 17, Neighborhood Youth Association
 

"During a 6 week summer program, The Story Project gave an amazing opportunity to 18 Howard County Middle School students to explore the world of writing through their own creative eye. By the middle of July, these children were hard at work as a team, defining their story's theme and identifying the main problem in their Story Project.  Within their unified effort, they identified the characters, blocked each act, and worked on props and costumes.   It was a thrill to be involved in this empowering experience and to see the excitement in our student's eyes as they shared their productions on Premiere Night with their family and friends."
- Julie Egert, Site Project Coordinator
 

I was extremely excited to be involved with The Story Project's East Coast pilot program. I thought the entire process itself had a structured curriculum (e.g., reviewing the components of developing a good story), as well as a unique organic element to it that allowed for students to fully conceptualize the project and get involved from start to finish. I appreciated how the shyest student and the outgoing extrovert could find themselves equally involved in The Story Project - and both could flourish! Julie and yourself quickly established a strong rapport with the students; instruction was very hands-on and delivered in a friendly and welcoming atmosphere. Including mentors added a further dimension to the process by having these experts share their experiences from the field. I look forward to working with you again!
- Carmen Albuerne, Information Specialist & Instructor, Howard County Library  East Columbia Branch, Columbia, MD 21045
 

Every week, the students and I look forward expectantly to 3:00, Thursday.  That’s when Todd and Bethany bring us fun activities, brilliant mentors, and involve us in memorable experiences like Peace Jam at Loyola Marymount University. I watch as they bring out the story teller in previously reluctant, unmotivated kids. When kids learn to create stories, you can see that they are learning about themselves and growing in confidence. They really do get inspired!
- Clifton Winnard, Teacher librarian, Mark Twain Middle School, Los Angeles, CA.

The Story Project staff and mentors encourage kids' creativity and self confidence.  They motivate the kids to discuss, write and develop their own ideas as well as share them with the group. The Story Project unites the kids in collaborating as a team,pooling their ideas and deciding on a common group theme.  They then work together on an exciting goal, in our case a short film. The result was a memorable and educational experience that allowed the kids to explore many facets of the entertainment arts as well as to grow in self esteem.
- Sherry DeLizia, Creative Arts Director, Boys and Girls Club of Burbank and Greater East Valley.

story:
Madagascar LIVE part 2 January 7th -January 23rd

 Madagascar Live! Wildlife Kids Club International! And many more programs like these are going to help kids around the world.

 

 I am very compassionate about sharing nature with kids! For ten years I worked as a licensed veterinary technician and loved my job. However, deep down I wanted to do more. On December 3, 2005, I watched the Tyra Banks show. Ms. Banks opened the show that morning with these words, “This show is about following your dreams!” Since then, I have never looked back.  I have successfully run my company, Erik's Reptile Edventures, for the past six and a half years. I am truly grateful for this opportunity and universal gift to reach thousands of children. 

 Last year I developed a distance learning program called Madagascar Live. In November, 2011, we went to Madagascar. This trip turned out to be a life changing experience.

 The program was the first of its kind in the village of Ranomafana to utilize Skype as the medium to communicate class lessons to children in the United States. I was grateful to all who participated and for the overwhelmingly positive response from the children and teachers!

  As a result, the not for profit organization called Wildlife Kids Club International was born! The mission is environmental education for children in impoverished villages throughout the world! We plan to begin this mission by starting our first Environmental Education Center in the village of Ranomafana, Madagascar. 

 We are hoping to raise $50,000 to fund the Environmental Education Center. This will have an immeasurable impact on the lives of the children in Madagascar and worldwide! The goal is to have these centers in several countries by the year 2020.

 This campaign is truly an effort to help bring positive changes to the world. I sincerely believe that every child should have the opportunity to know that we are all part of nature. It is so important for us to have an understanding of the connectedness between us and all of the inhabitants of our planet.

 

I know times are tough, but I hope that you can participate in the Madagascar Live campaign. I will be traveling to Madagascar in January  2013. Based on the success of Madagascar Live in November 2011, I look forward to a very successful January 2013 and hope you will all be able to support us in any way you can.

 

See you in Madagascar!

Peace, Joy and Happiness Always

Sincerely,

Erik Callender

If we raise $50,000 to support the Environmental Education center in Madagascar: 

    1. This funding will be applied within a two year funding period to build infrastructural capacity.
    2. It will be used as seed money to increase staffing and our program provisions which in turn will increase revenue and therefore serve as self-sustaining efforts.
    3. Erik’s Reptile Edventures has evidenced a steady revenue increase of 25% over the past three years. With the proposed following staff increase we project a revenue increase of at least 35% in “year one” and 50% in “year two.”
    4. Projected staffing in year one : (2) part-time distance learning instructors,30 dollars per day (2)part-Computer technology expert; 30 dollars per day (1)Part- time office manager, 30 per day.  The anticipated annual salary pay-out $7,050.00 will be based on a starting salary of $10.00 per hour for each position. Salary increases will be performance based which is a built-in incentive and commitment to the business. 
    5. $2000.00 will be used to support ten global shared learning experience events with Malagasy and US Schools please inquire with Erik's Reptile Edventures for further information. www.edventureshow.com

     Our programs will run every Saturday morning for 47 weeks per year.

     Building Supplies and Renovations.

    We estimate that the renovations for our building would run approximately $10,000.00 and the rent will be approximately 200 per month $2,400.00 per year.

    Technological supplies

    2 Printers $600.00

    6 Computers to be used with in the center - approximately $6,000.00

    Projector + backup - approximately $1,200.00

    Weekly Supplies. 

    Based on receipts from last year’s program includes: 

    • Paper supplies, Pencils and Crayons - approximately $40.00 per week 
    • Internet Service - approximately $50.00 per month 
    • Healthy snacks for kids - approximately $50.00 for up to 50 kids 

     

    Travel expenses 

    Travel within the country to and from Antananarivo will run approximately 400.00 round trip the drive is 10 hours each way.  total for two years 800.00

    Erik' Reptile edventures currently covers the cost of the flight. 

     

    The grand total to build and operate our center for the next two years will be $47,030. 

    Any additional funds will be donated to Wildlife kids club international to continue  the mission of building environmental education centers for impoverished villages world wide!

     

    What you get!!

    All who participate in our fundraising campaign will receive lots of cool perks including:Our latest Madagascar LIVE wildlife graphic T-shirt that features, Crazy Chameleons, Fantastic Frog and the Creepy cockroach additions!! Shirts include codes to view your animal on the go or from your smartphone, I Pad, or at home on your PC or Mac!

     

    You will all get to be in Madagascar Live on Skype! I will be skyping several times during this trip to update all of you on the progress of  the Trip!

     

    Additionally, 2,000 dollars of the funds raised will support hosting for our United States programs at the Sweet Briar Nature Center, Seatuck Environmental, center, and the South Shore Nature center in Long island New York. These centers will be the hub for our just approved not for profit Wildlife Kids Club International. Our kids and the kids in Madagascar will have the opportunity to have nature lessons Live from New York! 

    All supporters and friends are welcome to participate in our events! Join us for our first program on December 22nd in Long island!.

     

    The Impact

    If we raise the $50,000 to fund the Environmental Education center in Ranomafana, this will be the beginning of a change that will have an immeasurable impact on the lives of all of the children who participate including our children in the U.S.  

    Many of the children in Madagascar cannot afford to go to  Elementary school. This nature center will be the only hub for education many of the children will ever have since elementary school is not mandatory in Madagascar. 

    Additionally, our children in the U.S. face issues such as: 

    Game and television addiction, and many  kids simply don't spend enough time outdoors exploring! The opportunity for children to learn about our environment and all of its inhabitants is priceless! 

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't donate anything, no worries at all! Spreading the word about this is just as important! I deeply appreciate all of your efforts to support this initiative!

     Thank you, Thank you, and Thank you Again!

     Peace, Joy and Happiness Always! 

    Love Erik

story:
My Personal Story

Hello and welcome everybody! My name is Alina.  I am 20 years old and I from Germany. But, at the moment, I live on the island of Negros Oriental in the Philippines. After I finished high school, I came to the Philippines to work as a volunteer in a community-based organization for 1 year.  Here I am able to experience a new culture away from home while I learn from and help people.  Along with my local team members, we work to enrich the lives of children with opprtunities and skills they do not receive at home or in school.


Our Work

Our little organization is called Bright Lights Community Learning Centers Inc. (BLCLI) and we offer free extra-curricular education for children of all ages in the small farming and fishing villages of Bonbonon and Si-it.  About 70 children visit our two learning centers every Saturday from 8 am till 4 pm. Our curriculum focuses on several skill areas including arts and self-expression, basic computer skills, English reading and writing, and livelihood skills such as cooking healthy food.  We keep the lessons fresh and fun with a variety of topics to edu-tain the children.  We practice skits, make bracelets, learn to vegetable garden, practice self-defense and first aid.  Our children come from families who work hard to provide for their basic needs and Bright Lights aims to offer the children materials and learning opportunities they would not otherwise have access to in their subsistence villages.  You can learn more about the BLCLI on our website- www.blcli.org. 

 

The Summer class - EVERY DOLLAR COUNTS!

During the 2 month summer holiday in April-May, Bright Lights Learning Centers sessions are held 3 days a week.  During these extra sessions we focus on visual arts and require materials, such as pencils, paint, paper, beads, and food for student meals. Our goal is to reach at least 70 children at the two Learning Centers and each dollar counts.  For example, $1 = 6 pencils or two meals for our children. 

The Perks

Our organization has been sustained for nearly 4 years by the generous contributions of individual donors.  In order to continue reaching our children your donation will be used entirely for materials and meals during our summer sessions.  You will be recognized on our website and receive photos and videos showing how your donation enriched our children--the "Bright Lights" of our community. 


Other Ways to Help

Please spread the word about our campaign amongst family, freinds, co-workers and your community in person and via facebook and Twitter.  Contact us via our webiste for more information about our organization, our community and our children and ways you may donate funds and materials.

THANK YOU

story:
Hello Everyone,

My name is Hugo Morales, when I started college I was 19. I'm the first one in my family to ever go to college. I come from a very poor family, we used to live in Downtown Los Angeles since I was a kid, then my family and I moved to Burbank. And that is where my dream of becoming an Electrical Engineer seemed reachable, everything was going great until one day in the middle of my second semester I got very sick and went to the emergency room and the doctors diagnosed me with vertigo. Vertigo is a kind of feeling that you get that makes you feel as if you or your surroundings are moving when in reality there is no actual movement. You may feel as though you are spinning, whirling, falling, or tilting, and if you have severe vertigo you constantly have nausea and vomit. You have trouble walking or standing, and you may lose your balance and fall. Therefore I could not go to school anymore because of my vertigo, I talked to my doctor and my school, to be approved for a medical leave.

The school approved it but towards the end of August I got a letter saying I owed financial aid money. I was soon informed that it did not matter if I was too sick to finish school, I had already attended school for more than half of the semester and Financial Aid insisted for their money back. So I had no choice but to get a job, and when everything seemed to be going well, my mother and I got hit by a car. Due to the accident I became responsible for rent and the care of my mom. So its been almost a year and have not gone back to school and I had lost all hope until I saw a website called indiegoo where people donate to help people achieve their dream. So now I beg you for you to help me achieve my dream to go back to school!

The link below is proof that i got approved by the school to go on medicial leave and not because i was not doing well in school

 http://s1309.beta.photobucket.com/user/jack_hug...

Where Will The Money Go Too

All the donated money will go to me in order for me to attend school and help pay for books, and anything school related. None of the money will go anywhere else, 100% of your donated money will go to school and only school I promise you that.

Since I barely make money and the money I make goes to taking care of my mom I will find a way to give something back to you for donating and I am also willing to give some of my stuff away.

I cannot stress enough how important this is to me and what an impact it will have in my life. So please i beg you help me achieve my goal THANK YOU!

The school approved it but towards the end of August I got a letter saying I owed financial aid money. I was soon informed that it did not matter if I was too sick to finish school, I had already attended school for more than half of the semester and Financial Aid insisted for their money back. So I had no choice but to get a job, and when everything seemed to be going well, my mother and I got hit by a car. Due to the accident I became responsible for rent and the care of my mom. So its been almost a year and have not gone back to school and I had lost all hope until I saw a website called indiegoo where people donate to help people achieve their dream. So now I beg you for you to help me achieve my dream to go back to school!
The link below is proof that i got approved by the school to go on medicial leave and not because i was not doing well in school
 http://s1309.beta.photobucket.com/user/jack_hug...
Where Will The Money Go Too
All the donated money will go to me in order for me to attend school and help pay for books, and anything school related. None of the money will go anywhere else, 100% of your donated money will go to school and only school I promise you that.
Since I barely make money and the money I make goes to taking care of my mom I will find a way to give something back to you for donating and I am also willing to give some of my stuff away.
I cannot stress enough how important this is to me and what an impact it will have in my life. So please i beg you help me achieve my goal THANK YOU!

story:
Our Story

Charles founded Choo Smith Youth Empowerment, a 501(c) 3 non-profit organization that focuses on his “4L” philosophy (Love It, Learn It, Live It, Lead It).  Choo trains young athletes to work hard, persevere, and improve their basketball skills.  While he has made them successful on the court, he has found that some are not as successful in the classroom.

 

Due to the economic state of the country, school districts have been forced to make tough financial decisions in an effort to balance the budget.  The budget cuts translate into teacher layoffs, causing overcrowding in the classroom.  Larger student-to-teacher ratios are not always conducive to learning for all students.  Based on all of these factors, Choo made the decision to expand our services to include an educational component.

 

Our tutoring, private school entrance exam prep, transition readiness, and SAT prep courses are offered to students in grades 7 through 12 and compliment the school curriculum.  We service a large number of underprivileged children, and in an effort to ensure afordability we offer scholarships to minimize the cost.  The scholarships are funded through benefactors and donors interested in helping children succeed in the classroom and in life.

 

Choo published his first Children’s Book, “That’s Big, I Want To Have My Own Baseball Field” in April 2011. As a humanitarian, Charles “Choo” Smith has and continues to touch the lives of youth throughout Maryland and across the world.   Some of his humanitarian efforts include:

· Conducted basketball clinics in Israel as part of a goodwill delegation of current and former NBA players with Sports Power International.  During the trip he was personally introduced to the President of Israel, Shimon Peres.

· Participated in a back to school book bag give-a-way with partner Diakon/Kathryn’s Kloset

· Read a book to a first grade class at Pimlico Ele/Middle School’s “Book for Breakfast” program during American Education Week.

· Assisted in giving coats to homeless men at the Helping Up Mission in Baltimore, MD at The Annual Coat Give-a-Way event with the Baltimore Ravens/Diakon/Kathryn’s Kloset.

· Read his new children's book "That's Big" to a group of children at Easter Seals.  

Choo has received numerous awards and recognitions for his work and service in the community with children and youth.  Some of these awards and recognitions include:

· Received the 2011 Presidential Volunteer Services Award

· For the first time in the 85 Year history of the Harlem Globetrotters, they partnered with a former player to raise funds to help underprivileged children attend the 2011 Choo Smith Summer Basketball Camp.

· Received Content of Character Award from the Baltimore County Office of Fair Practices and Community Affairs

· Serves as the Honorary Chair for Healthcare for the Homeless’ Chocolate Affair.

· Choo Smith Basketball Camp was brought to Fort Bragg Military Base in North Carolina.

 


 

The Impact

Donations to the scholarship fund will give Choo Smith Youth Empowerment the financial resources to provide more educational and life skills programs to children in need of these services.

 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

We need to raise $50,000 in order to offer scholarships to 100 underprivileged children.  The scholarships provided will allow these children the same opportunities as those that have the means to afford such programs.  In addition to your donations, we are seeking grant opportunities and other fundraising efforts to fund our programs. 

 

The goal is high but attainable.  If we get 1000 people to help...

 

1000 donations of $50 = $50,000

500 donations of $100 = $50,000

50 donations of $1,000= $50,000

While our goal is $50,000, we will still move the program forward if we do not reach our goal.  While we are seeking grant opportunities and holding fundraisers, we still need your help because grants are not always funded in a timely manner. 

 

As our way of saying thank you for your donation, Choo Smith will send a personal thank you and a personally autographed photo for every donation of $100 or more.  For those donors that donate $500 or more Choo Smith will send a personal thank you, autographed photo and we will provide 4 free tickets to a Harlem Globetrotter game when they come to your area.


Other Ways You Can Help

SPREAD THE WORD.  If you are not in a positon to give at this time you can help us in other ways.  What if you could help us raise the money?  You could set a goal to raise $50, $100, even $500, either way any amount will help us reach our goal. 

 

visit our web site www.chooyouth.com to learn more about us.

story:
FRIDAY NIGHT JAZZ COMMUNITY FESTIVAL and                       SCHOOL SUPPLY GIVEAWAY

Friday and Saturday September 28-29 2012

Each One Teach One And Each One Reach One and the Culture Will Survive!!

What We Need & What You Get

Hello, we are Denise King and Suzanne Burgess, Jazz vocalist and Monica Allison President of Cedar Park Neighbors. We have joined together to bring music and education to the community...WE NEED YOUR HELP!!  QUICKLY!! On Friday September 28 and Saturday September 29th we are hosting a FREE event!! ALL ARE WELCOME!!

With the end of summer rapidly approaching and our children returning to school, it is our desire, but also we feel our duty, to help them excell by supplying them with the necessary tools to begin a succesful school year. Our goal is to bring music back to the community with an educational component. This is necesary because the arts are being eliminated from our public school curriculum and because it exposes the children to the genre of Jazz music. The concerts will also offer a safe place for seniors to enjoy music that many of them grew up with. No barriers or no cover charges...FREE. This event will bring the community together through music and education and hopefully leave a lifelong impression on everyone in attendance

In 1999, Denise King along with Bill Coleman founded a community based Jazz Series. Every Friday from Memorial Day to Labor Day we hosted FREE concerts for my neighborhood in West Philly. Because of the number of children present, Denise  started a literacy program BeBop and Books. Children were given books to keep trade or give back. Musicians were hired and paid through grass roots fundraising efforts and neighborhood sponsors. We even passed the bucket. In 2008 because funding dried up and my personal schedule no longer made it possible to make a weekly commitment, the series dwindled to one concert a month if that. Sadly BeBop and Books stopped. No more free books for kids.

It was an awesome event that impacted many in the community. It boasted a culturally and ethnically diverse audience all who loved Jazz. We all enjoyed the music, the sense of community and friendship. For two hours every Friday we came together as one big happy family.

We need to raise $8,000 to buy books, backpacks, other school supplies and also need to compensate musicians to perform and sound crew. Any dollar amount is wonderful and will help tremendously.

For any contribution your name will be listed on our program.

For your $10 donation you will receive a custom T-Shirt designed by a local artist

While $8,000 is our goal, If we don't reach that number, every dollar will be used to purchase as many backpacks and school supplies as we can and as well hire as many musicians as we can.

The Impact

Many children start school at a disadvantage. With the economy being so bad many people simply can't afford the bare necessities. Every child should be able to start school with the tools that they need to learn and to be good students. This campaign will address that need for, we hope, at least 100 children. It will take the pressure off of some parents who struggle to make ends meet and who simply don't have the means can't afford to buy their children everything that they need. The music component will be an educational experience for these kids. Many children, because music programs have been discontinued in schools, have never seen a real instrument or seen real musicians play. My hope is that it will impact or inspire some to pick up and instrument and explore the world of music. We chose this weekend because it is the culmination of my Denise King's European tour...I will be coming home. This was laid on our hearts to do. We need your help!!
 
.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, but want to help:

Ask everyone you can think of to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.Share this link on your FB page or email it to a friend

If you want to mail a donation please send it

C/O Denise King P.O. Box 16693 Philadelphia, PA 19139

 Indiegogo has great share tools!

And that’s all there is to it.

visit me online denisekingsings.com with questions or other ways to help

story:
Dear redditors,

I am a 19 year old who is humbly asking for help from fellow internet lurkers. I have been accepted to a higher-end University and unfortunately can not afford tuition and residence fees on my own. I realize that this post may sound like someone begging for money, but I assure you, this is not something I would be writing had I any other option. My parents immigrated to Canada so I could live the life they could only dream of living back home. With that being said, they worked 2 minimum wage jobs each just so our family could survive when I was younger. With whatever income they had, they were just breaking even. All that to illustrate that unlike the other kids whose parents created RESP accounts for them, I did not have that privilege. Midway through high school, I had truly realized the sacrifice my parents made for me and decided enough was enough and the slacking off had to be put to an end. That was when I started putting effort into school work. All in all, I graduated high school with an GPA of 82% in my top six classes. I was the first person in my extended family to ever graduate high school, let alone receive acceptance to a University. Also, I was accepted to my first choice university and now risk having that offer withdrawn because I cannot afford to pay for tuition. For all those who will tell me to get a job, I am working part time and use this money to aid my parents in paying off bills, etc. So all I ask is that you donate anything you can. That would greatly make me grateful and once again have faith in humanity.

Sincerely,

-M

story:
My wife and I had gone to see the Dr. He had told us that my wife has Endometriosis, Ovarian cysts, & precancerous cells. We thought we were dealing with a Dr. who knew what he was doing. He said our only way to fix this was a full hysterectomy. We latter found out, that wasn't our only option....

 

     As I was fading in and out waking up from the anesthesia, I cried out for Billy. The nurses told me he couldn’t come to the recovery room. Tears were rolling down my face as I heard a nurse ask if she could take me to my room to see him. A few moments later I was in the elevator trying desperately to open my eyes to make sure I saw Billy again. Entering the room that I would be staying at for the next two days recovering from my hysterectomy, I saw him; the man that loves and supports me even in the darkest of moments. With my eyes barley opened, tears lightly started to fall down my face; I muttered to him, we would never be able to have children. In that moment, I felt hopeless.


     Gathering the pieces of a broken heart and putting them back together is a journey. As we continue on our path, we have now reached the road to adoption. We have reached this point with open arms; not worrying about the sex of the baby or the color of skin, but the ability to love a child with open arms. Unfortunately, the fees are deep and our pockets are not wide enough to cover the $25,000 minimally in the adoption process. 


     No matter how big or small a donation is or what form it comes in, every little bit makes a difference on our journey to becoming parents. Thank you for being a part of our lives and helping us out on our journey. There are no words that we can express in our over flowing amount of gratitude to you for being open hearted and listening to our story. God bless you!


Billy and Theda Currin


“Love is more than a noun- it is a verb, it is more than a feeling- it is caring, sharing, helping, and sacrificing.”

--William Arthur Ward

story:
SMALL SCHOOL, BIG DREAM: Help Espacio a go on school trip to New York City!

WHO ARE WE?

Espacio a is a learning community for children and youth ages 3 to 18 years old.  Founded in 2007 as a non-profit organization and located in Old San Juan, Puerto Rico, we are the only independent democratic school on the entire island.

Espacio a’s mission is to empower people and to transform human relations.  Our learning community is based on natural, integral and dynamic learning and on the principles of participatory democracy and non-violent communication.  At our school students not only learn the traditional academic subjects but also the important lessons of compassion, community and positive social interactions.

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR HELP?

For three years we have been talking about taking a trip together with our entire school community, and now an amazing opportunity has presented itself!  Three weeks ago we were invited to attend the NADEC (North American Democratic Education Conference) in New York.  At first this idea sounded impossible and far fetched.  Nonetheless as a democratic learning community, naturally we started to brainstorm ideas and started to get excited about the idea.  We decided that not only could we attend the conference, but that we might be able to visit New York City, which is only one hour away from the NADEC site.  Most of our students have never visited New York City or the United States and they were very excited about the possibility!  We spoke with other New York schools like ours and decided that we could visit with them and also do some community service to support families who have been affected by Hurricane Sandy.  Many of our students are also excited to be visiting one of the most amazing cities in the world and visit famous sights such as: Central Park, Statue of Liberty and The Museum of Natural History

WHAT WILL WE USE THE FUNDS FOR?

We are a group of 30 students, teachers and parent chaperones and we need to raise $20,000 in 30 days to help cover the travel costs for our trip.  These costs include plane tickets, food, housing and transportation. 

WHAT WILL YOU RECEIVE FOR YOUR SUPPORT?

We have a wide range of incredible rewards for those of you who support our efforts.  Many of these gifts are one of a kind items, hand crafted by our students and local Puerto Rican artists.  They include photos, t-shirts, paintings and crafts.  And of course you will receive a huge thank you from all of us at espacio a!

THANKS FOR YOU SUPPORT!

We hope you will help us reach our goal and make this trip a reality for our kids.  We believe this trip is an important opportunity for our students to bond with their peers at other democratic schools, have new experiences, practice their english skills and help others in need.   For many of our students who have never traveled outside of Puerto Rico, we believe this trip will be a truly transformative experience.

We also hope you will help us spread the word about our campaign and share this with your friends, family and contacts on social networks, email and word of mouth. 

Thank You!!!
From the students, teachers & parents at espacio a

story:
Help Me Help Young Girls In Liberia Get Off the Streets and Into School!!!!

Hi, my name is Gretchen Everman and I am becoming a fellow at an amazing organization known as More Than Me, which helps young girls in the poorest slums of Monrovia, Liberia get off the streets, out of the brothels, and into school.   It was founded in 2009 by Katie Meyler, a woman who I immediately became friends with when we met and who has inspired me to take a leap of faith in my life and join this amazing cause.  In doing so, I am asking for help so that I can travel to Liberia to meet the girls at the MTM Academy and get a better understanding of the "behind the scenes" operations.  This will help me gain insight on the organization and I will then be able to travel back to the states to help launch our NYC headquarters. 

What your donations will cover:

Even if you can only donate a $1, every bit counts!

I am asking for $3500 total to cover the following costs:

$1800 flight from NYC to Liberia

$1200 misc. travel expenses (visas, food, housing, etc. for a month)

$500 Training expenses, Tour Guide, Supplies for the girls, cost of campaign, etc.

More Than Me:

ABOUT US

We get girls off the street and into school in one of the poorest slums in the world in Liberia, West Africa. We work with community leaders to identify the girls who are at the highest risk of being sexually exploited to ensure that education and opportunity, not exploitation and poverty, defines their lives. We pay tuition, provide school lunch and we work with the school and community to make it impossible for her to fail. It's working, 10% of our girls are 1st in their class!

HOW IT STARTED // Read founder's story

WHY GIRLS?

Educating one girl changes, well, everything. Here's why:

  • When a girl in the developing world receives seven or more years of education, she marries four years later and has 2.2 fewer children.
  • An extra year of primary school boosts girls' eventual wages by 10 to 20 percent. An extra year of secondary school: 15 to 25 percent.
  • When women and girls earn income, they reinvest 90 percent of it into their families, as compared to only 30 to 40 percent for a man.

Help Spread the Word:

If you have read this far, I am sure you are just as excited about this organization as I am!  Please help me out by spreading the word 1) about my personal fund raiser to get to Liberia and 2) about More Than Me.  You can like us on Facebook and visit our website.  This is an amazing opportunity and I can't wait to share with all of you my journey and the stories of these beautiful little girls!
story_txt:
Help Me Help Young Girls In Liberia Get Off the Streets and Into School!!!!
Hi, my name is Gretchen Everman and I am becoming a fellow at an amazing organization known as More Than Me, which helps young girls in the poorest slums of Monrovia, Liberia get off the streets, out of the brothels, and into school.   It was founded in 2009 by Katie Meyler, a woman who I immediately became friends with when we met and who has inspired me to take a leap of faith in my life and join this amazing cause.  In doing so, I am asking for help so that I can travel to Liberia to meet the girls at the MTM Academy and get a better understanding of the "behind the scenes" operations.  This will help me gain insight on the organization and I will then be able to travel back to the states to help launch our NYC headquarters. 
What your donations will cover:
Even if you can only donate a $1, every bit counts!
I am asking for $3500 total to cover the following costs:
$1800 flight from NYC to Liberia
$1200 misc. travel expenses (visas, food, housing, etc. for a month)
$500 Training expenses, Tour Guide, Supplies for the girls, cost of campaign, etc.
More Than Me:
ABOUT US
We get girls off the street and into school in one of the poorest slums in the world in Liberia, West Africa. We work with community leaders to identify the girls who are at the highest risk of being sexually exploited to ensure that education and opportunity, not exploitation and poverty, defines their lives. We pay tuition, provide school lunch and we work with the school and community to make it impossible for her to fail. It's working, 10% of our girls are 1st in their class!
HOW IT STARTED // Read founder's story 
WHY GIRLS?
Educating one girl changes, well, everything. Here's why:

When a girl in the developing world receives seven or more years of education, she marries four years later and has 2.2 fewer children.
An extra year of primary school boosts girls' eventual wages by 10 to 20 percent. An extra year of secondary school: 15 to 25 percent.
When women and girls earn income, they reinvest 90 percent of it into their families, as compared to only 30 to 40 percent for a man.
Help Spread the Word:
If you have read this far, I am sure you are just as excited about this organization as I am!  Please help me out by spreading the word 1) about my personal fund raiser to get to Liberia and 2) about More Than Me.  You can like us on Facebook and visit our website.  This is an amazing opportunity and I can't wait to share with all of you my journey and the stories of these beautiful little girls!

story:
The Now's the Time Project

Thank you for viewing our campaign. We are Terrell and Claudio Martinez, the founders of the Now’s the Time Project. We are parents and grandparents and have a profound love for all children. Their innocence, beauty, wide-eyed sense of wonder, honesty, unconditional love and unlimited imagination are our inspiration. This project was born of our vision and heartfelt desire of being active co-creators of a better world for our children and to help children in need.

We have over 40 years professional experience as a teacher and practitioner in the healing arts and 30 years as a professional in the entertainment industry respectively. This is a mission of love that enables us to utilize our individual and collective gifts as a unified force of love to "be the change." Like Leela and Kathleen (two of our singers) say in our promo video,"We're all in this together." Together we can impart a powerful multi-media message in support of children everywhere and bring joy (through live music, sharing, storytelling and wonderful giftbags) to children in need.

Our Mission

- is to bring love, joy, inspiration and hope to children in need and to creatively empower children everywhere. By combining the universal languages and healing frequencies of music (sound) and art (color) with storytelling we are delivering a powerful and positive message.

                                       

               * the voices of the humpback whales help empower the children.

 Our Message

- Now’s the Time to honor our divinity, both individually and collectively, embrace the power of love and release all fear. We are all infinitely more beautiful and powerful than we have heretofore been led to believe. It’s time for humanity to rise and shine, transcend our differences, claim our power and unify as conscious co-creators and make this world a better place for our children.

                        

                    *the dolphin voices help inspire and bring joy to the children.

 We wrote and produced, “Now’s the Time,” a powerful, uplifting and healing original song in honor of all children: with three prodigal young musical artists supported by four world-class studio musicians, the voices of whales and dolphins and a slice of magic by a Grammy-award winning artist/composer/ arranger. Its creation and evolution was an incredible divinely led journey. World renowned “Art of My Soul” angel artist, Giorgio Tuscani, has painted three phenomenal original paintings in support of our project. His artwork will grace our CD, some of the promotional items, some of the items for your perks and items for the gift bags for our  …

Children in Need - Live Music and Gifting Campaign

At the heart of this campaign are the gift bags and live music performances we are planning for the children in the different wards of Millers Children’s Hospital in Long Beach, California.  Kathleen and some other top performers are ready for action. The hospital is waiting for our call to let them know when we are coming. Other hospitals are waiting in the wings. We just need our team together and van packed with the necessary supplies. We plan to be there within two months of funding. We are grateful to our great group of sponsors who are making their products, resources and services available for some of your perks and the children’s gift bags. It’s all lined up.

What We Need:

Funds for the materials and services necessary to produce the six item gift bags for hospital campaign (t-shirts, posters, stickers, wristbands, live-action underwater dolphin DVD and our CD). The services required include: digital imaging, silkscreening, graphics/logos, printing, replicating, duplicating, graphic design, plus materials for 500* gift bags.*(We need to have extra on hand for the patients siblings).

Funds for a batch of promotional items (same as above) to help spread the word, the message and engender global support - we have already received great feedback from elementary school teachers who have played "Now's the Time for their students and we'd love to give out batches of free download cards and whenever possible, free cd's.

A really cool initial music video that's worthy of the song for promotion (You Tube, etc). 

An incredible website where people experience our vision and story, meet our (ever expanding) team, join in, network and empower the movement. The website will be an amazing experience with virtual portals and fluid moving imagery with our dolphin and whale allies and an original cast of colorful characters who will help us engage, inspire and eduate the children. It will also provide entrees to the other aspects we are developing - videos, apps, games, films and illustrated storybooks with very special attributes.

Social Media - we want to reach MILLIONS of people as quickly as possible and this requires the resources to hire the right people (that we have) and facilitate this.

Travel, lodging and basic expenses (for two weeks) for Kathleen - lead singer and youth ambassador who lives in Massachusetts and basic expenses (food and gas) for the local team (artists/performers) for this first children’s hospital campaign. They're volunteers coming from different areas, however, we would like to pay for their gas to staging points and buy them lunch each day.

Cargo Van Rental – 2 weeks.

2 man video crew – 2 weeks (filming).

Hire our team – Artists, Illustrators, Graphic Artist, 3D Visual Artist, Web, IT, Social Marketing Expert

We also wish to present Millers Children's Hospital with the gift of a full sized framed Giclee of Giorgio Tuscani's original oil painting "Unconditional Love - Now's the Time."

We have the personnel to do all this – we simply need your help so we can put them to work.

 

Where the Money Goes:

 

The Money We Raise..

..will be used in the most efficient way to fulfill our goals in as many complete steps as is made possible. Exceeding our goal will afford us many options in going beyond the goals of this first phase. We can start another hospital gifting and performance campaign, embark on the filming of our live action short film/music video for "Now's the Time" and produce more music and art that supports the mesage. There is a great deal that we can do and we have an abundance of talented individuals we can put to work.

What You Get:

The knowledge that your heartfelt energy helped bring love, joy, inspiration hope and some great gift bags to hundreds of children in need. That’s priceless. You’ll also get some wonderful perks made possible by Giorgio Tuscani’s art and other amazing sponsors in fields ranging from the arts to health and wellness who are in alignment with our mission.

Other Ways To Help…

Spread the word. Visit our Now’s the Time Project Facebook page, LIKE and SHARE it. Tweet and blast an email to everyone you know that cares about our future and that of our children. Write Now’s the Time Project on Indiegogo in lipstick on the rear window of your car. Connect us to Ellen or Oprah or anyone with media links or outlets. Let this story become meaningful conversation while you are standing in lines at the grocery store or at the banks. Dialogue this adventure as we watch the children bring love to the earth. Help us by speaking up whenever you have an interview or get a mic in your hand. Entice all your favorite social media friends to toot our horn. Show how easy it is for your mom, your uncle and your grandma to share Indiegogo on facebook and twitter. Let’s get this campaign to go viral.

 

Why we’re doing this?

Kathleen Regan (above left) and Zukari Collins and Leela Ladnier (above right), the three brilliant young voices on the song are perfect representations of the brilliant future that awaits an awakened humanity. They are loving, kind, compassionate, wise, peaceful and happy. Our children are more than the future generations, they are the future and the future starts now. It’s all about love...in action.

As Leela said in the promo video. "The age of ME is over. The age of WE has just begun."

 

                                                     

 

A little more About Us

 

We are from the Kona Coast on the Big Island of Hawai'i. In addition to the children we get a great deal of joy and inspiration from the dolphins and whales who inhabit the waters and in which we swim. Their voices, beauty, grace and energy have had a profound effect on our lives.

We have a vast network of (and strategic alliances with) high level professionals in many fields, from the arts and entertainment industry and education to health and wellness and even Quantum Physics who are in alignment with our vision and mission and plan to work with us. All of them have, quite literally appeared on our path - that's how we know we are working with angels..

Some of them are...

Our Sponsors:

        

                                           

   

                                                            

 

Giorgio Tuscani Art, State of the Heart Fitness, Michal and Company (Crystals and Semi-precious stones) , Healthy Habits USA (Scalar Energy Health and Wellness Products), Song of Home.com. Carlos & Christy White Eagle Designs. ,

 

 A peek at some of the Perks:

Original 36"x36" "Unconditional Love - Now's the Time" Oil painting by Giorgio Tuscani - the cover art and art for the stickers, handwritten thank you cards,  T-Shirts, limited edition prints and giclees.

 

 

 Now's the Time engraved - energy enhanced Rose quartz crystal.

 

 

 Live action underwater dolphin DVD.

 

 Energy Medallion will be engraved with "Now's the Time"

story:
Economic, Political and Societal challenges continue to considerably prevent many of those living in developing economies from gaining the education that is their right. 

Therefore, we are creating flexible and diverse opportunities for these under-served demography to gain access to quality higher education learning through the use of internet and mobile technologies.


  • Campus Master Plan and Conceptual Study (July 2013) 
    As part of our vision to provide American campus style experience for our university community (staff, teachers and students), we completed a conceptual study taking into account the beauty and aesthetics for an interactive campus. Learn More
  • Development Land Acquisition for Campus Development (May 2013)
    BAU acquired over 105 acres of development land required for the development of a multi-million dollar university campus that will accommodate over 10,000 students on campus upon its completion. Learn More
  • Start of Online Programs in Entrepreneurship (April 2012)
    BAU started its 12 week Entrepreneurship and Innovation certificate program designed for the study of all aspects of starting a business venture. The students will recognize and find their potential for creating a business venture or marketable product/ idea. Learn More


It has been an inspiring journey so far for us. In the past one year we have reached so many students through our Entrepreneurship and Innovation courses helping a few towards the path of creating their businesses and supporting them subsequently.

We have diversified from an Online-only university to a Hybrid university and now we are taking the big step towards creating a full physical campus as an On-Campus university.

We have encountered so many challenges that has led us to learn more about our industry, our unique market and how best to navigate reach more students in developing countries.

However, the cost of the overheads become a burden often times. We need to figure out ways to offset some these costs so that we can conclude the development plans and construction of our campus in time for the next academic year.

We hope that we can get your donations and this will contribute towards the funds we need to cover basic operational expenses, outreach, outsourcing and consulting.


Your Contributions will go towards

  • Funding Outreach Programs to recruit more students for our Entrepreneurship and Innovation Online Classes.
  • Funding Scholarship Programs to make the Entrepreneurship and Innovation Online Classes more affordable for students in under-served communities.
  • Funding Research initiatives on the use of Feature Phones and SMS to implement Mobile Learning frameworks in developing countries where internet access is a challenge.
  • The Development Consulting on Technical and Policy Requirements (So many documents need to be prepared by different experts, designers and architects). (Some of this has started)
  • Funding Pre-Development work on the university development site and interviews by the MoE.


We were fortunate to have the amazing Jen Gallagher design the 1st Phase of our campus, spread out on over 105 Acres of bare development Land. This phase covers faculty buildings, recreational facilities, housing, administrative offices, a hospital, utilities and academic support buildings.

The Campus Plan / Map:

As much as we are ensuring that our campus is beautiful, we also ensuring that it is lead by inspiring minds and the best instructors we can afford. We are also ensuring that our students will be those who can easily integrate into the culture we are developing (Excellence, Openness, Flexibility and Innovation).

We have also developed extensive partnerships to ensure we cover every aspect of education and learning by focusing on the core - Learning and Development and outsourcing the support systems through our partnerships.

One of such is with Fora - which is providing worthy high end Ivy League Accredited Courses at the fraction of the cost for our students to take advantage of.

We will continue to build on our Successes and reach as many students as we can in all regions across Africa, Europe and Asia.


The country’s tertiary learning systems are in a mess. They haven’t been upgraded since the 1970s. Rather than leaving the problem to the politicians, Gossy Ukanwoke is creating an online university called Beni American University for Nigeria - Daily Maverick
Nigeria’s first online university has been launched by Gossy Ukanwoke who has been nicknamed Nigeria’s Mark Zuckerberg. - Channels TV / Reuters Africa
We are bringing the best of all worlds: Social + Education. Students/teachers get to learn from each other based on personal knowledge and research - Forbes
The university, founded by Gossy Ukanwoke, a 24-year old Nigerian, was created to fill up the valley in the Nigerian educational system which is primarily due to infrastructure challenges - Ventures Africa

Why is PayPal not activated?
Unfornunately, PayPal does not work in our region of operation and as such we cannot maintain our PayPal account from here.

How did you arrive at the funding target?
We took an average of the each of the costs / needs we specified under "Your Contributions". 

How will the contributions be spent?
Some of our needs have fixed costs and others do not. We will logically share the contributions towards the flexible needs and fully fund needs with fixed costs assuming we meet our funding goal.

What if your funding goal is not met?
We appreciate every support we receive during our fundraising, and every backer will be welcomed into the BAU Patriot community. If we don’t reach our target, all received contributions will be added to our current funds as we continue to take advantage of our other funding sources.

My questions are not answered here
We are happy to hear your questions, suggestions and contributions. Please feel free to email us at info@beniamerican.org or visit our website for more information.

story:
Gearhearts Steampunk Glamor Revue Needs YOU!

What are we?

We're a Steampunk pinup magazine. A lavish Steampunk extravaganza. Gorgeous Steampunk models in intricate, neo-Victorian garb; reviews, interviews, artistic expressions, and even some prose thrown in for good measure. 

Why are we asking you for money?

We want to expand.  We'd like to put together a real website.  We'd like to start a line of merchandise (t-shirts, posters, shotglasses - anything you can think of, we want to make). We'd like to attend more conventions so we can chat about gorgeous Steampunk in person.  Most importantly, we'd love to be able to pay artists and photographers what they deserve instead of what we can currently afford (hint: it's nowhere near what their talents are worth).

That sounds great. What do I get out of the deal?

Besides our undying gratitude? Lots! There are all sorts of perks listed on this page, from buttons to magazines to starring in a Lucky K. Holliday story to an actual partridge in an actual pear tree. 

We know the economy is tough.  We know you're broke.  So are we. If you can give anything at all, we'll put your name on a special thank you page on the website.

We also have an exclusive offer for the first three cherished donors who offer $100 or more.  The fantastic artist Brigid Ashwood, whose breathtaking Steampunk creations will appear in issue 6, has generously offered prints of her artwork for this project.  The first three people to donate $100 or more will receive a print of one of her most gorgeous pieces of art. (Her shop for the interested: http://www.etsy.com/shop/brigidashwood?ref=si_shop)

Gearhearts Steampunk Glamor Revue Needs YOU!
What are we?
We're a Steampunk pinup magazine. A lavish Steampunk extravaganza. Gorgeous Steampunk models in intricate, neo-Victorian garb; reviews, interviews, artistic expressions, and even some prose thrown in for good measure. 
Why are we asking you for money?
We want to expand.  We'd like to put together a real website.  We'd like to start a line of merchandise (t-shirts, posters, shotglasses - anything you can think of, we want to make). We'd like to attend more conventions so we can chat about gorgeous Steampunk in person.  Most importantly, we'd love to be able to pay artists and photographers what they deserve instead of what we can currently afford (hint: it's nowhere near what their talents are worth).
That sounds great. What do I get out of the deal?
Besides our undying gratitude? Lots! There are all sorts of perks listed on this page, from buttons to magazines to starring in a Lucky K. Holliday story to an actual partridge in an actual pear tree.

story:
Problem

Lack of resources and guidance to new studnets getting enrolled in the pharmacy course and due to this they end up with wrong decision and lead to disappointmnet.

Studensts are not aware about the various career options available and also they do not have proper understanding of the pharmaceutical industry trend. 

Today due to increase in number of colleges and increase in the competition, jobs are shrinking and in such situation such guidance from this website would act like a good teacher.

Introduction

My self a pharma professionals working in pharma industry. I have gone through very hard phases during my education in pharmacy due to lack of guidance and resources.

I have already buid up this website (mypharmaguide.com) with my own expenses and tried to keep it as informative as possible. However due to lack of time and resources not able to keep it alive.

What We Need & What You Get

I need $500 to keep it upgraded and renewd plus make it more resourceful with the help of dedicated team from the pharmacy field.

Upgradation of website (30%)

Recruting Team (40%)

Data entry (10%)

Content build up (10%)

Creating awareness (10%)

 

The Impact

  • This will provide free platform to all pharmacy students.
  • It will fill the gap between academic student and industry professional
  • Allow platform for any students to publish their research without any fees or limitation.
  • Allow freshers to browse vacancy in the respeceted field.

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to donating, you can also help us in these ways:

Share the Campaign: By any means like facebook, twitter, linkedin etc

Write about this: Write about mypharmaguide.com and spread awareness

Give feedback: Give your feedback and suggestions to improve
